Summary: 36 % name one of the broadcast networks .

Context: What is t he opinion of Republicans and Republican leaners about Trump changed the tone of political debate ?
Summary: Half say he has changed the nature of political debate in the country for the better , while 28 % say he has n’t changed it much and 21 % say he ’s changed it for the worse Far more conservative Republicans say Trump has changed U.S. political debate for the better than for the worse ( 61 % vs. 12 % ) . By contrast , moderate and liberal Republicans are about as likely to say he ’s changed debate for the worse ( 35 % ) as for the better ( 33 % ) .

Context: Describe the public opinion over the US military campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria.
Summary: About six - in - ten Americans ( 63 % ) approve of the U.S. military campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria ; just 26 % disapprove of the campaign . Support is somewhat higher today than in August 2014 ( 54 % approved ) .

Context: What is the opinion of public regarding U.S. going its own way?
Summary: Two years ago , Pew Research Center found an increase in the proportion of Americans who agreed that “ since the U.S. is the most powerful nation in the world , we should go our own way in international matters , not worrying too much about whether other countries agree with us or not . ” The percentage agreeing jumped to 44 % . But in the new survey , the number saying the U.S. should go its own way in the world has fallen back to 35 % , which is more in line with measures over the past few decades ; 62 % disagree with this statement , up from 51 % in 2009 .

Context: How is the picture of Labor Union declining among people?
Summary: Currently , 41 % say they have a favorable opinion of labor unions while about as many ( 42 % ) express an unfavorable opinion . In January 2007 , a clear majority ( 58 % ) had a favorable view of unions while just 31 % had an unfavorable impression .

Context: What are trends in US Latino population?
Summary: the growth of the U.S. Latino population has slowed since 2007 , when the Great Recession started .

Context: How is the Hispanic public distributed between the Democratic and Republican parties?
Summary: Some 57 % of Hispanic registered voters now call themselves Democrats or say they lean to the Democratic Party , while just 23 % align with the Republican Party – meaning there is now a 34 percentage point gap in partisan affiliation among registered Latinos

Context: Describe the proportion of employed mothers who say that being a working mother makes it more difficult for them to progress in their jobs or careers?
Summary: employed moms ( 50 % ) are more likely than employed dads to say being a working parent makes it harder for them to advance in their job or career .

Context: How is local employability seen?
Summary: 33 % say there are plenty of jobs available where they live , while 58 % say that jobs are difficult to find .

Context: Write some details about female share of the labor force?
Summary: Women may never make up half of the U.S. labor force . Women accounted for 46.8 % of the U.S. labor force in 2015 . Although women comprised a much larger share of the labor force in 2015 than in 1950 ( 29.6 % ) , the Bureau of Labor Statistics projected the share of women in the workforce will peak at 47.1 % in 2025 before tapering off .

Context: Describe the trend in seniors in owning tablet or e-book reader and smartphone.
Summary: Some 27 % of seniors own a tablet , an e - book reader , or both , while 18 % own a smartphone .

Context: Compare the number of Americans that uses different social media platforms.
Summary: Nearly eight - in - ten online Americans1 ( 79 % ) now use Facebook , more than double the share that uses Twitter ( 24 % ) , Pinterest ( 31 % ) , Instagram ( 32 % ) or LinkedIn ( 29 % ) .

Context: How much does the U.S. immigration system need to be changed, according to the Hispanic population, compared to Asian Americans?
Summary: Hispanics are more likely than Asian Americans to say the U.S. immigration system needs to be “ completely rebuilt ” or needs “ major changes”—62 % of Hispanics say that , compared with 47 % of Asian Americans .

Context: Describe trends in partisan differences of opinions about UN?
Summary: The share of Democrats who have a positive view of the UN is generally higher than the share of Republicans who say the same , but the partisan gap has been especially large since 2013 . That year , 72 % of Democrats and 41 % of Republicans expressed a favorable view – a difference of 31 percentage points . This year , Democrats are 41 points more likely than Republicans to see the UN positively ( 77 % vs. 36 % ) . The share of Republicans who currently have a favorable view of the UN is at its lowest point in almost 30 years .

Context: What are the most popular social networks among children aged 11 and under?
Summary: Platforms like TikTok and Snapchat are more popular than Instagram among children 11 and younger , according to their parents .

Context: What do conservative Democrats say about a friend who voted for Trump?
Summary: Far more conservative and moderate Democrats say a friend voting for Trump would not have any effect ( 73 % ) than say it would put a strain on the friendship ( 25 % )

Context: How do the percentages of Americans between white protestants and white evangelicals differ along with their party identification?
Summary: The proportion of the population composed of white evangelicals has changed very little ( 19 % in 1987 ; 22 % now ) Republicans outnumber Democrats among white evangelicals by more than two - to - one ( 51%-22 % ) Today , white evangelicals make up 22 % of the population , and constitute nearly four out of every ten ( 39 % ) Republicans

Context: Compare partisan confidence in Angela Merkel in 2012 and in 2017.
Summary: In 2012 , there was virtually no difference in the views of Democrats and Republicans , but in 2017 , 64 % of Democrats had confidence in the chancellor , compared with 50 % of Republicans .

Context: How is the public's interest in news about the airplane tragedy?
Summary: The airline tragedy was the top story for 10 % of the public .

Context: How's the partisan affiliation among U.S veterans?
Summary: Last fall , Trump held a wide 60%-34 % advantage over Hillary Clinton among veterans , according to the national exit poll conducted by Edison Research for the National Election Pool as reported by CNN Eight years earlier , veterans backed John McCain over Barack Obama by 54 % to 44 % . ( The national exit poll did n’t ask about veteran status in 2012 . )

Context: Describe how different do Democrats men and women perceive discrimination about women.
Summary: In views of discrimination against women , fairly comparable shares of Republican women ( 58 % ) and men ( 47 % ) say women face at least some discrimination . Democrats – both women ( 86 % ) and men ( 81 % ) – are far more likely than Republicans to see discrimination against women . However , a greater share of Democratic women ( 51 % ) than Democratic men ( 35 % ) say women face “ a lot ” of discrimination in our society

Context: What did the countries say about the economic power of the U.S.?
Summary: South Korea is the most likely to say that the U.S. is the leading economic power ( 66 % ) , followed closely by Japan ( 62 % ) Roughly half say the U.S. is the world ’s economic leader in Israel ( 52 % ) , Vietnam ( 51 % ) , Hungary ( 51 % ) and the U.S. itself ( 51 % ) .

Context: What was the U.S. population composition by race/ethnicity in 1960s?
Summary: The U.S. population reached 200 million in the mid to late 1960s . At that time , the U.S. population was 84 % white , 11 % black , 4 % Hispanic and 1 % Asian and Pacific Islander .

Context: What is the distribution of worlds migrant population?
Summary: In 2015 , almost one - in - five ( 19 % ) of all international migrants lived in the U.S. , and 23 % were in the EU , Norway and Switzerland .

Context: What is the diversity distribution of millennials?
Summary: More than four - in - ten Millennials ( currently ages 22 to 37 ) are Hispanic ( 21 % ) , African American ( 13 % ) , Asian ( 7 % ) or another race ( 3 % ) . Among Gen Xers , 39 % are nonwhites

Context: Describe some information about Jews have the most years of schooling Globally?
Summary: While there are big gaps in average education levels among different religious groups , these disparities have been narrowing in recent decades because those at the bottom made the biggest educational strides . A new Pew Research Center study , analyzing data from 151 countries , looks at education levels of Jews , Christians , Buddhists , Hindus , Muslims and religiously unaffiliated adults ages 25 and older . The demographic study also examines changes in educational attainment over three recent generations . When measured by years of formal schooling , Jews have the highest average educational attainment , while Muslims and Hindus have the lowest . Christians have the second highest average years of schooling , followed by religiously unaffiliated adults and then Buddhists .

Context: Describe the trend between Republicans and Democrats on US foreign policy toward Iran?
Summary: while 68 % of Republicans say it is more important to take a firm stand against Iranian actions , the balance of opinion is flipped among Democrats . Roughly seven - in - ten Democrats ( 71 % ) say it is more important to avoid a military conflict with Iran . Just a quarter of Republicans ( 25 % ) say it is more important to avoid a conflict , while a similar share of Democrats ( 23 % ) say they would prefer that the U.S. take a firm stand against Iranian actions .

Context: Tell about local tv newsroom budgets in 2012?
Summary: In the vast majority of TV newsrooms , budgets either grew ( 49 % ) or held steady ( 39 % ) in 2012 . Only 6 % of news directors said they had to make cuts .

Context: What are the Black adults' thoughts on police spending?
Summary: About four - in - ten Black adults ( 42 % ) say spending on police in their area should decrease , including 22 % who say spending should be decreased a lot . One - third of Black adults say spending should stay the same , while 22 % say it should be increased .

Context: Compare how countries in Latin America perceive power of U.S. ?
Summary: Compared with concerns about Russian or Chinese influence , worries about U.S. power and influence are relatively high in Argentina , Brazil , Mexico and Tunisia . More than half in these countries say U.S. power is a major threat to their country . By comparison , concerns about the U.S. are relatively lower in sub - Saharan Africa and Israel .

Context: What are Europeans opinions about Saudi Arabia record on civil rights?
Summary: opinion of Saudi Arabia ’s record on civil rights is highly critical in Europe , where as many as eight - in - ten or more in Spain ( 86 % ) , Greece ( 84 % ) , and France ( 81 % ) think the Saudi government does not protect the personal freedoms of its people .

Context: What is the Americans opinion about U.S global position in 2020 ?
Summary: About six - in - ten Americans think their country has the world ’s strongest economy , increasing from only half in 2019 . Similarly , about eight - in - ten think the U.S. is the world ’s leading military power , an increase from 72 % in 2016 . In addition , an overwhelming majority of Americans agree that the world would be better off with the U.S. as the leading power , rather than China .

Context: Describe how Dominicans describe themselves in terms of identity.
Summary: “ Dominican ” is the identity term used most often . two - thirds of Dominican adults ( 66 % ) say they most often use the term “ Dominican . ” Some 16 % say they most often describe themselves as “ American . ” Roughly the same share ( 17 % ) most often use the terms of “ Hispanic ” or “ Latino ” to describe their identity .

Context: What is the opinions among the American public regarding federal spending cuts?
Summary: 60 % saying automatic federal spending cuts would have a major effect on the U.S. economy and nearly as many ( 55 % ) say the same for the U.S. military . Fewer ( 45 % ) say the cuts would have a major impact on the federal budget deficit , while just ( 30 % ) think their own personal finances would be affected in a major way .

Context: How much do Americans support the idea of giving more power to the president in dealing directly with the problems of other countries?
Summary: Just 17 % of Americans say that “ many of the country ’s problems could be dealt with more effectively if U.S. presidents did n’t have to worry so much about Congress or the courts , ” while 77 % take the view that “ it would be too risky to give U.S. presidents more power to deal directly with many of the country ’s problems ” .

Context: How does knowledge of QAnon vary based on social media platform?
Summary: people who got news from Reddit or Twitter are most likely to say they ’ve heard or read a lot ( 8 % and 6 % , respectively ) or a little ( 39 % of Reddit users and 31 % of Twitter users ) about the conspiracy theories .

Context: How does the public view recent economic news?
Summary: About six - in - ten ( 59 % ) say they are hearing mixed economic news compared with 32 % who say they are hearing mostly bad news and 8 % who say they are hearing mostly good news .

Context: Describe the changes that are going to happen in the demographic profile of veterans?
Summary: Between 2013 and 2043 , the share of all veterans who are women will almost double , from 9 % up to 17 % , according to VA projections . At the same time , the share ages 50 to 69 is expected to shrink from 42 % to 34 % , while the share ages 70 or older is expected to rise from 30 % to 36 % . Mirroring trends in the overall U.S. population , the veteran population is predicted to become more racially and ethnically diverse , as well . Between 2013 and 2043 , the share of non - Hispanic white veterans is projected to fall from 78 % to 64 % , while the share of Hispanic vets will likely double , from 7 % to 14 % .

Context: What does the public in the EU nations think about extramarital affairs?
Summary: Across the EU nations polled , a median of 65 % deem extramarital affairs unacceptable .

Context: Describe about Putin's handling of issues?
Summary: Despite Russians ’ lukewarm view of the economy , a majority ( 55 % ) still approves of Putin ’s handling of the issue . Putin also has the support of more than half the country when it comes to energy policy and civil society . The only area included in the survey in which he fails to earn majority approval is the issue of corruption .

Context: Describe the public news interest on the plans to burn Koran?
Summary: Nearly two - in - ten ( 17 % ) say they followed the controversy over the pastor ’s announcement that he would burn Korans more closely than any other major story .

Context: Which political party has more favorable views on Oprah Winfrey?
Summary: Currently , 59 % of Republicans say they have a favorable opinion of Winfrey down from 64 % last October , and 75 % in January 2007 . About a third of Republicans ( 32 % ) now view Winfrey unfavorably , up substantially since January 2007 ( 21 % ) .

Context: Compare the news knowledge results obtained from verbal and visual question?
Summary: according to the Pew Research Center ’s latest News IQ survey , which for the first time includes visual questions . While majorities answer most of the 19 questions correctly , some prove more difficult . About four - in - ten , for example , know that Republicans now hold a majority only in the House of Representatives or can identify the crescent and star from four visual choices as the symbol associated with Islam . Seven of the 10 items with the most correct answers are visual questions . In addition to the large majority ( 82 % ) that correctly pick a photo of Hillary Clinton from four when asked which showed the current secretary of State , 79 % select the name “ Moammar Gadhafi ” from a list of four when shown a photo of the former Libyan leader . On a map of South America with four nations numbered and highlighted , 77 % correctly identify Brazil .

Context: How are the partisan's views on transgender issues?
Summary: While eight - in - ten Republicans and Republican - leaning independents say that whether someone is a man or a woman is determined by the sex they were assigned at birth , most Democrats and Democratic leaners ( 64 % ) say a person ’s gender can be different from the sex they were assigned at birth .

Context: What does adults think about using cellphone in each situation?
Summary: Americans see cellphone use as OK in key public spaces , but not in more private or intimate gatherings . For instance , about three - quarters of Americans think it is generally acceptable for people to use their cellphones while walking down the street ( 77 % ) , on public transit ( 75 % ) or waiting in line ( 74 % ) . But only 38 % think it is generally OK to use cellphones at restaurants , and very few say cellphone use is OK at a family dinner ( 12 % ) , during a meeting ( 5 % ) or at church ( 4 % ) .

Context: What are the opinions about Nawaz Sharif?
Summary: Opposition leader Nawaz Sharif fares better : 63 % express a positive opinion of the Pakistan Muslim League ( PML - N ) leader .

Context: Describe the drop in the support for the death pennalty in the U.S. since 1996.
Summary: A Pew Research Center survey conducted in April and May 2018 found that 54 % of Americans favor the death penalty for people convicted of murder , while 39 % oppose it . That was up from 2016 , when 49 % of U.S. adults said they favored the death penalty , compared with 42 % who opposed it . But it was far lower than in 1996 , when 78 % of Americans supported capital punishment for those convicted of murder .

Context: What is the opinion of Democrats and Republicans about responsibility of federal government in ensuring home broadband?
Summary: Roughly half of Democrats ( 52 % ) say the federal government has a responsibility to ensure that all Americans have a high - speed internet connection at home during the COVID-19 outbreak , while just 22 % of Republicans hold his view

Context: What is the trend when it comes to online harassment?
Summary: Those who have been harassed by someone they know are also more likely to turn to others for support : 55 % sought out some type of help or support during their most recent indident , compared with 31 % of those who were harassed by a stranger or somone anonymous . This group is especially likely to turn to other friends or family members for support : 39 % did so after their most recent encounter , compared with 16 % of those whose harasser was unknown to them .

Context: Write some information about differing trajectories of Trump?
Summary: In April 2016 , the average thermometer ratings for Trump among both Converts and Skeptics were very low ( 27 among Converts , 24 among Skeptics ) . By contrast , the average rating among Enthusiasts was 85 .

Summary: Germans are also very positive when rating their own country ’s job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak : Nearly nine - in - ten ( 88 % ) say the country has done well

Context: Explain the opinion of third generation Americans with Hispanic ancestry about identifying them as Hispanic?
Summary: By the third generation – a group made up of the U.S.-born children of U.S.-born parents and immigrant grandparents – the share that self - identifies as Hispanic falls to 77 %

Context: Describe the proportions of Mexicans who want to move and do not want to move to the U.S.
Summary: the percentage of Mexicans who are inclined to move to the U.S. remains steady at roughly a third ( 34 % ) . Summary: A majority ( 57 % ) of the British public said they favor more restrictions on entry into the UK

Context: describe the impact of phones in 11 emerging economies?
Summary: mobile phone users largely agree that their phones help them get news . A median of 79 % of mobile phone users across the 11 countries surveyed say their mobile phones have helped them get information and news about important issues . A median of 64 % of adults also say people should be very concerned about exposure to false or incorrect information when using their mobile phones .

Context: What were trends in stock ownership among US adults?
Summary: Gallup ’s annual economy and finance survey , conducted in April , found 52 % of Americans saying they owned stock , either directly or through a mutual fund , retirement account or other investment vehicle .

Context: What is the range of U.S. adult population considered as multiracial ?
Summary: In a 2015 study that used a broader definition of the term – one that took into account how adults described their own race as well as the racial background of their parents and grandparents – Pew Research Center estimated that 6.9 % of the U.S. adult population could be considered multiracial

Context: What was the opinion of most veterans on the Iraq war?
Summary: Among veterans , 64 % say the war in Iraq was not worth fighting considering the costs versus the benefits to the United States

Context: How Americans' thoughts are utilitarian-oriented when it comes to thinking about education's role in society?
Summary: Six - in - ten adults say the public K-12 education system has a lot of responsibility in making sure the U.S. workforce has the right skills and education to be successful in today ’s economy , according to a Pew Research Center survey conducted in 2016 The only entity or institution that more people say has a lot of responsibility is “ individuals themselves , ” cited by 72 % of adults . Americans express a bit more ambivalence toward the role of colleges and universities in workforce preparation , with around half of adults ( 52 % ) saying these higher - education institutions should have a lot of responsibility in making sure workers have the right skills and education to succeed .

Context: Describe the amount of oppositional posts of Democrats on Facebook.
Summary: The analysis finds that Democrats expressed political opposition nearly five times as much under Trump as they did during the last two years of Barack Obama ’s presidency . Much of this opposition was directed at President Trump , though Democrats also increasingly opposed Republican members of Congress .

Context: Compare white and black officers views about the way they are treated by the media?
Summary: White officers ( 43 % ) , are more likely than their black colleagues ( 34 % ) to strongly agree that the media treat police unfairly .

Context: In Americans' opinion, which party leads the best when it comes to immigration?
Summary: But the Democratic Party has made sharp gains compared with a year ago on several issues – notably , foreign policy and immigration . Currently , 49 % of Americans say the Democratic Party is better able to make wise decisions about foreign policy , while 36 % favor the GOP . A year ago , Republicans were favored on foreign policy , 46 % to 38 % . Democrats also lead on dealing with immigration , 50 % to 39 % ; in recent years , the parties have run about even on this issue .

Context: How has panel interviews been conducted among the different devices?
Summary: When the panel began , nearly two - thirds of respondents took their surveys on a PC or laptop . That share declined quickly through 2014 and 2015 and has continued to gradually decline since then . In a November 2018 wave of the panel , just over half of the interviews were conducted on a smartphone , while 39 % used a PC or laptop . About 8 % took the survey on a tablet computer , a figure that has remained fairly stable since the panel was created .

Context: What are trends in the ratings on Obama's job among different age groups?
Summary: Barack Obama ’s job approval rating , has fallen substantially since the start of his presidency , across all age groups . In September , 58 % of voters younger than 30 approved of Obama ’s job performance , down from 71 % in February 2009 . Yet younger voters remain far more supportive of Obama than any other age group . By comparison , voters ages 30 to 49 are divided in their assessments of Obama , and a clear majority of those age 50 and older disapprove of the job Obama is doing .

Context: What do different races say about making it easy for everyone to vote?
Summary: Blacks are more likely than either whites or Hispanics to say voting should be made as easy as possible for citizens : 79 % of blacks say this , while just 19 % say citizens should have to prove they really want to vote by registering ahead of time . Among whites , a much narrower majority ( 54 % ) support making voting as easy as possible for all citizens ( 44 % say citizens should prove they want to vote by registering ahead of time ) . By 64%-35 % , most Hispanics support taking steps to make voting easy for all citizens .

Context: Describe the growth of the Christian population in some regions of the Middle East.
Summary: Between 1900 and 2010 , the total number of Christians in the region – including Egypt , Iraq , Israel , Jordan , Lebanon , Syria and the Palestinian territories – grew from 1.6 million to 7.5 million .

Context: How were the voters' expectations of Trump before the election?
Summary: Across five specific areas , majorities of voters gave negative marks to a possible Trump presidency : 61 % said that if Trump were elected , he would definitely or probably not set a high moral standard for the presidency ; 57 % said he would not improve U.S. global standing ; 55 % said he would not improve the way government works and the same percentage said he would not run an open and transparent administration . About half ( 52 % ) said he would use his office to improperly enrich himself or friends and family .

Context: What are partisan views about the decision of entering the war?
Summary: more Republicans than independents ( 42 % ) or Democrats ( 33 % ) say the war was the right decision .

Context: Comment on the satisfaction of people over the result of Presidential Elections?
Summary: Overall , a majority ( 56 % ) say they are satisfied with the results of the election , compared with a third ( 33 % ) who are dissatisfied . One - in - ten do not have an opinion either way .

Context: Describe the opinion of Biden and Trump supporters about the other candidate.
Summary: Biden and Trump supporters say they fundamentally disagree with each other not just on political priorities , but on core American values . eight - in - ten registered voters who supported Biden ( 80 % ) – and a similar share of those who supported Trump ( 77 % ) – said they fundamentally disagree with the other side on “ core American values and goals . ” Only around one - in - five in each group said their differences are limited to politics and policies .

Context: What is public impressions when it comes to economic news between 2009 and 2013?
Summary: 59 % say they have been hearing a mix of good and bad news about the economy , 28 % say they have been hearing mostly bad news while 10 % say they have been hearing mostly good news in February 2009 , 60 % said news about the economy was mostly bad , 37 % said it was mixed and just 2 % said news about the economy was mostly good .

Context: What are Turks' views about refugees?
Summary: Turks are insistent that fewer of them should be crossing their borders . Two - thirds say that Turkey should allow fewer refugees from Syria and Iraq into their country . Only 8 % are willing to accept more refugees , while 13 % would like to keep the flow about the same as it is now .

Context: What opinion do the Western European public have about immigration restrictions?
Summary: Majorities in the other Western European countries included in the 2009 poll also expressed support for tougher restrictions on immigration . About eight - in - ten in Spain ( 80 % ) and Britain ( 78 % ) shared that view , as did 65 % in Germany and 64 % in France .

Context: How do Republicans and Domecrats say about each other?
Summary: more than half of Republicans ( 52 % ) view Democrats as more closed - minded than other Americans , nearly as many say Democrats are more immoral ( 47 % ) , lazier ( 46 % ) and more dishonest ( 45 % ) .

Context: What are the U.S. Views on Trade?
Summary: About two - thirds ( 68 % ) of Americans say that growing trade and business ties between the U.S. and other nations are good for the country . However , only one - in - five Americans think trade with other countries creates jobs . Similarly , only 17 % of the general public says trade leads to higher wages . more than half the American public thinks both TPP and the TTIP would be good for the country .

Context: How do U.S. adults think about covid-19 outbreak?
Summary: about one - third ( 32 % ) fall into the high distress category ; among those who say it is not a threat to their health , just 16 % do . And 30 % who see the outbreak as a major threat to their personal financial situation fall into the high distress category , compared with 18 % among those who say it is not a threat

Context: What is people's opinion on whether Muslim Americans are discriminated a lot?
Summary: 45 % say that Muslim Americans face a lot of discrimination , and 28 % say they are subject to some discrimination . Only about one - in - five say that Muslim Americans face only a little ( 13 % ) or no discrimination ( 6 % ) .

Context: Describe the trend in the number of bills passed by each Congress' first August recess.
Summary: Congress passed 49 measures before its summer break . We categorize 35 of those acts as “ substantive ” . By contrast , the 112th Congress had passed just 28 pieces of legislation – 19 of them substantive – by the time its August 2011 recess rolled around , matching the level of the 104th Congress in 1995 . The 113th Congress was slightly more productive , passing 31 laws ( 24 of them substantive ) by its first August recess . In 2007 , Congress had passed 81 laws ( though 35 of them were ceremonial ) ; four years earlier , 79 laws had been passed by the time Congress went on its August break . The 106th Congress passed just 56 by its August 1999 recess .

Context: What is the opinion of adult on whether public libraries give trustworthy information and help in learning new things?
Summary: About eight - in - ten adults ( 78 % ) feel that public libraries help them find information that is trustworthy and reliable and 76 % say libraries help them learn new things

Context: How do South Koreans view US and China in terms of economic power?
Summary: South Koreans are the most likely to name the United States as the world ’s leading economic power — eight - in - ten say that is the case . About one - in - ten South Koreans ( 12 % ) say China is the dominant economic power .

Context: How are Hungarian's feelings about the refugees?
Summary: Roughly eight - in - ten believe refugees are a burden on their country because they take jobs and social benefits . Similarly , about three - quarters believe that refugees will increase the likelihood of terrorism in Hungary , and about seven - in - ten see the large influx of refugees from countries like Syria and Iraq as a major threat . These figures are much higher in Hungary than in almost every other EU nation surveyed .

Context: Divide and discuss about age groups based on whether they go online just for fun.
Summary: Americans are increasingly going online just for fun and to pass the time . On any given day , 53 % of all the young adults ages 18 - 29 go online for no particular reason except to have fun or to pass the time . the results of a survey by the Pew Research Center show that young adults ’ use of the internet can at times be simply for the diversion it presents . Indeed , 81 % of all young adults in this age cohort report they have used the internet for this reason at least occasionally . These results come in the larger context that internet users of all ages are much more likely now than in the past to say they go online for no particular reason other than to pass the time or have fun . Some 58 % of all adults say they use the internet this way . figures are higher than in 2009 when we last asked this question and vastly higher than in the middle of the last decade .

Context: What effects have various national institutions had on America?
Summary: Majorities of Americans say churches and religious organizations ( 59 % ) and colleges and universities ( 55 % ) have a positive effect . Nearly half ( 47 % ) say labor unions have a positive impact ; 32 % see their impact negatively . Views of the impact of banks and other financial institutions are more negative ( 46 % ) than positive ( 39 % ) . And by roughly two - to - one ( 63 % to 28 % ) , more Americans say that the national news media has a negative than positive effect on the way things are going in the country .

Context: What is the opinion of the public towards the question of whether wedding related business have the right to refuse services to a same-sex wedding?
Summary: There was an even split on this question , with 47 % saying that businesses should be allowed to refuse services related to same - sex weddings and 49 % saying they should be required to provide services as they would to all other customers .

Context: Describe the incarceration rate among U.S adults ?
Summary: At the end of 2016 , there were about 2.2 million people behind bars in the U.S. That amounts to a nationwide incarceration rate of 860 prison or jail inmates for every 100,000 adults ages 18 and older . The nation ’s incarceration rate peaked at 1,000 inmates per 100,000 adults during the three - year period between 2006 and 2008 .

Context: Describe the distribution of U.S. Indians who celebrate Diwali.
Summary: In the U.S. , seven - in - ten Indian Americans say they celebrate Diwali .

Context: What is the opinion among supporters of Biden and Trump towards candidate support ?
Summary: Around six - in - ten Trump supporters ( 59 % ) say they have a lot of friends who share their support for the president ’s reelection bid , while a slightly smaller share of Biden supporters ( 48 % ) say a lot of their close friends also back the former vice president in the election this fall

Context: Describe the public approval regarding the Obama administration and the Republican and Democratic leaders in Congress.
Summary: Barack Obama ’s job rating is , on balance , negative – 43 % approve . Just 20 % approve of how Republican leaders in Congress are handling their jobs . With just a 20 % approval rating , Republican leaders in Congress trail not only the president but also their Democratic counterparts ( 31 % approve ) .

Context: What opinion do the public have about the status on the interpretation of the constitution in recent years?
Summary: About half of the public ( 46 % ) says the U.S. Supreme Court should make its rulings based on its understanding of what the Constitution “ meant as it was originally written , ” while an identical share says the court should base its rulings on what the Constitution “ means in current times .

Context: What is the public views on the Iraq situation currently?
Summary: Two - thirds of Americans ( 67 % ) say that the U.S. military effort in Iraq is going not too well or not at all well . Just 30 % say things are going very or fairly well .

Context: Write some details about most Democrats, Republicans rate among Police Officers?
Summary: While 86 % of Republicans give officers warm ratings – and about three - quarters ( 74 % ) view them very warmly – a smaller majority of Democrats ( 57 % ) view officers warmly , and just 33 % give them very warm ratings .

Context: Describe the Obama personal positive ratings?
Summary: Fully 82 % say that Obama stands up for what he believes in ; 75 % said this a year ago . Nearly six - in - ten ( 57 % ) say Obama is able to get things done , up 11 points from a year ago , and 59 % say he is a strong leader , up seven points since then . 70 % said he was able to get things done and even higher percentages gave him positive ratings for other attributes .

Context: Comment on the global popularity of the US compared to Russia and China.
Summary: While Russia was still viewed far less favorably than either the U.S. or China last year , a sharp decline in America ’s favorability improved Russia ’s standing relative to the U.S. Overall , a median of 50 % had a positive image of the U.S. in 2017 versus 35 % who viewed Russia favorably . In previous years , 64 % across these same nations had a favorable view of the U.S. compared with a median of 28 % favorability for Russia .

Context: What part of the mothers said they left work to take care of family responsibilities?
Summary: Roughly a quarter ( 27 % ) said they had quit work altogether to take care of these familial responsibilities .

Context: How about the views on environmental regulation among partisans?
Summary: Views about environmental regulations are more partisan today than they were a decade ago . Roughly six - in - ten Republicans and Republican leaners ( 58 % ) said in another 2016 Pew Research Center survey that environmental laws and regulations cost too many jobs and hurt the economy , up from 34 % in 2007 . By comparison , a declining share of Democrats and Democratic leaners hold this view . This partisan gap now stands at 41 percentage points ; in 2007 , it was 10 points .

Context: What are the Black's views on making voting as easy as possible?
Summary: Blacks are more likely than either whites or Hispanics to say voting should be made as easy as possible for citizens : 79 % of blacks say this , while just 19 % say citizens should have to prove they really want to vote by registering ahead of time .

Context: What are the public's views on the positivity or the negativity of what they have been reading and hearing?
Summary: Close to half ( 48 % ) of the public says that what they were reading and hearing about the plan was “ mostly negative , ” while about three - in - ten ( 29 % ) say what they read and heard was “ mostly positive . ” Some 17 % say they saw a mix of both .

Context: Describe opinion of people about the Top National issues causing a big problem?
Summary: Among the issues tested , rising prices is the top concern . Just over three - quarters ( 76 % ) say inflation is a very big problem . Seven - in - ten or more also name crime , unemployment , corrupt political leaders , drug cartel - related violence and corrupt police officers as very big issues . Half or more say poor - quality schools , health care and people leaving Mexico for jobs in other countries are very big concerns . However , less than half name the gap between rich and poor , immigrants traveling through Mexico from Central America to the U.S. , or traffic as top worries .

Context: Describe the trend among Americans towards capitalism and socialism?
Summary: Overall , a much larger share of Americans have a positive impression of capitalism ( 65 % ) than socialism ( 42 % )

Context: Comment on adult averages of self-identified Catholics in the U.S. since 2007?
Summary: Catholic identification in the U.S. has held stable , fluctuating only between 22 % and 23 % .

Context: Explain the decline of the baby boomer generation in the American population.
Summary: The Baby Boomers are losing one of their best - known claims to fame – being the largest American generation – to the Millennials .

Context: What is the opinion of men and women about getting messages from dating apps and websites ?
Summary: Roughly six - in - ten men who have online dated in the past five years ( 57 % ) say they feel as if they did not get enough messages , while just 24 % of women say the same . Meanwhile , women who have online dated in this time period are five times as likely as men to think they were sent too many messages ( 30 % vs. 6 % )

Context: Describe how different generations think about spirituality.
Summary: they are as likely to engage in many spiritual practices . like older Americans , more than four - in - ten of these younger adults ( 46 % ) say they feel a deep sense of wonder about the universe at least once a week . Likewise , most also say they think about the meaning and purpose of life on a weekly basis ( 55 % ) , again , similar to older generations . Roughly three - quarters of Millennials feel a strong sense of gratitude or thankfulness at least weekly ( 76 % ) . And 51 % say they feel a deep sense of spiritual peace and well - being at least once a week .

Context: Which are the main reasons for climate change according to U.S. adults ?
Summary: Most U.S. adults think human activity , such as the burning of fossil fuels , contributes a great deal ( 49 % ) or some ( 32 % ) to climate change About two - in - ten ( 19 % ) say human activity contributes not too much or not at all to climate change .

Context: What opinion do millennials have about Dems election from social media?
Summary: Nearly three - quarters ( 74 % ) of Millennial Democrats who say they are very likely to participate in their state ’s primary or caucus learned about the 2016 presidential election through a social networking site . This is starkly higher than the 50 % of Millennial Republicans who say they are very likely to participate . These party differences were not found in other generations .

Context: What is the situation on what kind of information that voters say they would like to learn about Romney's record as governor ?
Summary: 41 % of voters say they would like to learn more about Romney ’s record as governor , 36 % would like to learn more about his tax returns , while 35 % want to know more about his record as chief executive of Bain Capital . Far fewer want to hear more about Romney ’s wealth ( 21 % ) , his family and upbringing ( 19 % ) or his religious beliefs ( 16 % ) .

Context: How's the English proficiency among the non-adult population, specifically among Hispanics?
Summary: Among children ( ages 5 to 17 ) in the U.S. for five years or less , 46 % speak English proficiently . This share rises to 84 % among foreign - born Hispanic children who have been in the country 11 to 15 years , and reaches 85 % among those in the country 16 to 17 years .

Context: What are partisan views on how Obama will be remembered?
Summary: There is a substantial partisan gap in views of how Obama will go down in history . Fully 71 % of Democrats and Democratic leaners say he will be remembered as an outstanding ( 30 % ) or above average ( 40 % ) president , while just 4 % predict history will consider him below average or poor ( 24 % expect him to be viewed as average ) . By contrast , nearly six - in - ten ( 57 % ) Republicans and Republican leaners say he will be remembered as below average ( 21 % ) or poor ( 36 % ) , while just 15 % say he ’ll go down in history as outstanding or above average ( 26 % say he ’ll be considered average ) .

Context: How have federal budget concerns changed over the months?
Summary: at 24 % , the number saying the federal budget deficit is their top concern also has risen , from 19 % in December and February .

Context: Compare news interests of oil leak to economy?
Summary: More than six - in - ten ( 63 % ) say they followed news about the oil leak more closely than any other story . Just 10 % say this about the second ranked story , news about the economy .

Context: Describe the percentage of people attentive to the Somalia food shortage.
Summary: Just 3 % each say that the food shortage in Somalia was their most closely followed story . About one - in - ten ( 12 % ) followed news about the famine in Somalia caused by severe drought and an ongoing civil conflict .

Context: Compare Trump's approval rate between GOP leaners and Republicans?
Summary: As of August 2020 , 62 % of GOP leaners say they approve of the way Trump is handling his job in office , compared with 86 % of Republican identifiers .

Context: How are the views on Hammas in different countries and territories?
Summary: Hamas receives relatively positive ratings in Jordan ( 56 % favorable ) and Egypt ( 52 % ) . However , Palestinians are more likely to give the group a negative ( 52 % ) than a positive ( 44 % ) rating .

Context: What opinion does public have about pre-emptive use of military cannot be justified?
Summary: About as many ( 48 % ) say such pre - emptive use of military force can rarely ( 28 % ) or never ( 20 % ) be justified

Context: How important do residents of Denver, Macon and Sloux City view the internet as a news source?
Summary: residents of Denver are most likely to say the internet is very important to keeping up with local news ( 45 % , compared with 38 % in Macon and 33 % in Sioux City ) .

Context: What is the proposition of Democratic party supporters who say climate change is affecting their local community at least a little?
Summary: More than eight - in - ten Democrats and independents who lean to the Democratic Party ( 83 % ) say climate change is affecting their local community at least some , compared with 37 % of Republicans and Republican leaners .

Context: What Americans think about candidates and coverage of various issues in campaigns ?
Summary: About four - in - ten say there is too much coverage of candidates ’ comments on the campaign trail ( 44 % ) and of their personal lives ( 43 % ) . This is followed by coverage of which candidate is leading in the polls ( 37 % ) and the candidates ’ moral character ( 30 % ) . Very few say the candidates ’ experience ( 15 % ) or their stances on issues ( 13 % ) have received too much attention

Context: Describe the rise in the number of children living with an unmarried parent in the U.S.
Summary: Overall , about one - in - five children ( 21 % ) are living with a solo mother , up from 12 % in 1968 . Some 7 % are living with cohabiting parents , about double the share that were doing so in 1997 ( the first year for which census data on cohabitation are available ) . The share of children living with a solo father has ticked up , and stands at 4 % , up from 1 % in 1968

Context: What are some information about younger generations outvoted boomer and prior generations in 2018?
Summary: Midterm voter turnout reached a modern high in 2018 , and Generation Z , Millennials and Generation X accounted for a narrow majority of those voters , according to a Pew Research Center analysis of newly available Census Bureau data . The three younger generations – those ages 18 to 53 in 2018 – reported casting 62.2 million votes , compared with 60.1 million cast by Baby Boomers and older generations .

Context: How are unpartnered adults living?
Summary: A narrow majority ( 56 % ) of unpartnered adults are the head of their household . Some 35 % are living alone and 22 % are living with others in the home ( single parents would fall into this category ) . Nearly three - in - ten ( 28 % ) are living with a parent or grandparent . An additional 16 % have some other relationship to the head of the household ( for example , a sibling or roommate ) .

Context: Describe some details about Russians still feel they should get more respect?
Summary: Most Russians still believe their country does n’t get the respect it deserves , but fewer feel this way now than in the past . Today , 56 % of the Russian public thinks Moscow should be held in higher esteem around the world . About a third believes Russia gets the proper amount of respect , which is up from just 16 % in 2012 , the last time the question was asked .

Context: What is the situation of the ventilator shortages in covid-19 period in American hospital?
Summary: Among the public , half ( 50 % ) say that , if a shortage occurs , the priority for critical care should be given to patients most in need at the moment while nearly as many ( 45 % ) say the priority should be to patients who doctors think are most likely to recover with treatment .

Context: Describe details about U.S. adults who have witnessing harassing behaviors directed toward others online?
Summary: 28 % of Americans say that observing the harassment of others has influenced them to set up or adjust their own privacy settings . But in other cases , widespread abusive behavior can have a more pronounced chilling effect : 27 % of U.S. adults say they have refrained from posting something online after witnessing the harassment of others , and 13 % of the population has elected to stop using an online service due to the harassment of others they observe .

Context: What is the distribution of social media users follow science pages or accounts?
Summary: About a quarter of social media users – 26 % – say they follow science pages or accounts

Context: What an American adult would say about social media towards the country?
Summary: A majority of U.S. adults ( 64 % ) say social media have a mostly negative effect on the way things are going in the country today , with Republicans being more likely than Democrats to express that view . The Americans who see a negative effect from social media point to factors including misinformation and the hate and harassment they see on these platforms .

Context: What was people's opinions of this years State of the Union address compared to past years?
Summary: 24 % say speech will be more important than past addresses , while 19 % say it will be less important ; 52 % say it is about as important as previous State of the Unions .

Context: What are some opinions about public perception of crime rate at odds with reality?
Summary: BJS data show that violent crime and property crime rates fell 26 % and 22 % , respectively , between 2008 and 2015 ( again , the most recent year available ) .

Context: Compare partisans opinions about Trump needs to release his tax returns.
Summary: fewer Republicans say Trump needs to release his returns than did so last year ( 28 % now , 38 % then ) . Democrats continue to overwhelmingly say Trump has an obligation to release his taxes ( 80 % say this )

Context: What are some concerns of the officers about fatal encounters between police and blacks?
Summary: Most officers – 86 % – say high - profile incidents between blacks and police have made their jobs harder .

Context: What is the opinion of Democrats and Republicans about the GOP?
Summary: Democrats and Republicans have somewhat similar views of the Republican Party ’s ideology : 64 % of Democrats and 51 % of Republicans say the GOP is either very conservative or conservative

Context: What do majority of Republicans think will be the reason that 2019 will be better than 2018?
Summary: Asked why they think 2019 will be better than 2018 , 24 % of Republicans volunteer Trump as the reason , while 20 % cite the economy . Roughly one - in - ten ( 12 % ) point to expectations around border security and immigration , including the possible expansion of the U.S.-Mexico border wall .

Context: What is the Americans opinion of police officers using excessive force?
Summary: Two - thirds of Americans ( 66 % ) say that civilians need to have the power to sue police officers to hold them accountable for misconduct and excessive use of force , even if that makes the officers ’ jobs more difficult . Just 32 % say that , in order for police officers to do their jobs effectively , they need to be shielded from such lawsuits .

Context: What were the statements given by Twitter users?
Summary: 39 % of the statements on Twitter shared news without any opinion . But of the statements offering clear views about the result , those expressing anger or opposition to the verdict ( 31 % ) outnumbered those in support of the acquittal ( 7 % ) .

Context: What is the trend in completing education by adults during the Obama years ?
Summary: In March 2009 , 41 % of 25- to 34 - year - olds had completed at least an associate degree . By March 2016 , 48 % of young adults had done so . A larger share of female 25- to 34 - year - olds ( 52 % ) had finished college in 2016 than their male counterparts ( 43 % )

Context: What proportions of test users say their results have changed the way they think about their racial or ethnic identity?
Summary: 15 % of mail - in test users say their results changed the way they think about their racial or ethnic identity

Context: Describe the partisan views on government's fight against terrorism.
Summary: Currently , 85 % of Democrats say the government is doing very or fairly well in reducing the terror threat , up 14 points since September . About six - in - ten ( 63 % ) Republicans give the government positive ratings ; at that time , just 40 % of Republicans said the government was doing well in addressing the of terrorism

Context: What are the general views and opinions on China?
Summary: A median of 47 % across the 38 countries surveyed have a favorable opinion of China , while 37 % express an unfavorable view . Majorities or pluralities in 24 countries give China a positive rating .

Context: What was trend in public interest in the Iraq war?
Summary: Public interest in the Iraq war peaked during the conflict ’s early phase in 2003 , and began to decline . Overall interest fell to 44 % in 2004 , on average . Throughout 2005 and 2006 , public attentiveness to the situation in Iraq fluctuated in response to news events , but on average about four - in - ten followed the story very closely in both years . In 2007 , public interest in Iraq has averaged 33 % . In the current survey , 31 % say they are following news about the situation in Iraq very closely .

Context: What are the partisan views on science marches?
Summary: Republicans and Republican leaners oppose the goals of the science marches by a 47%-25 % margin ; some 29 % are undecided about their views . Democrats and Democratic leaners support the goals of the marches by a 68%-14 % margin , with 18 % undecided .

Context: What proportion of Americans said that if robots and computers are capable of doing a lot of human work, it is the government's obligation to take care of displaced workers, even if it means substantially raising taxes?
Summary: Half of U.S. adults said that in the event that robots and computers are capable of doing many human jobs , it is the government ’s obligation to take care of displaced workers , even if it means raising taxes substantially

Context: What does the German population think about providing military force to NATO allies to face a Russian attack?
Summary: Germany has the fourth - largest defense budget in NATO , but just 40 % of Germans believe that Germany should provide military force to defend a NATO ally if it is attacked by Russia . More than half ( 53 % ) do not support such aid . There are no significant partisan differences on this issue among Germans . Opposition to providing military assistance is particularly strong among German women ( 62 % ) . Men there are largely divided on the issue . Among people who live in the states that comprised the western Federal Republic of Germany , 43 % think Berlin should come to the aid of a NATO ally . Just 29 % of those from the eastern states that were once the German Democratic Republic agree . In Poland , the NATO member state in the survey in the closest proximity to Russia , 62 % of the public backs using military force to defend a NATO ally . Such sentiment has increased significantly since 2015 , when 48 % wanted their nation to come to an alliance country ’s defense .

Context: What have American partisans heard of QAnon's conspiracy theories?
Summary: Knowledge of QAnon grew on both sides of the political aisle , though Democrats ’ awareness continues to outpace that of Republicans . As of September , more than half ( 55 % ) of Democrats and those who lean Democratic say they have heard at least a little about the conspiracy theories , compared with 39 % of Republicans .

Context: Describe how different education holders approves Barack Obama ’s presidency ?
Summary: Today , 62 % of those with postgraduate degrees approve of his job performance , along with 54 % of those with bachelor ’s degrees . Among adults with some college experience but no degree , 47 % approve , as do 49 % of those with no more than a high school degree .

Context: Describe Japanese views of China over time.
Summary: Japanese views of their neighbor China have also improved somewhat over time , but from a very low base . Just 17 % of the public holds a favorable impression of China , up 12 points from a low of 5 % in 2013 . Unfavorable opinion of Beijing has fallen 15 points since then , to 78 % .

Context: Describe the distribution of religious people who want gene editing in U.S.
Summary: Only 34 % of highly religious adults say they would want to employ gene editing to reduce their child ’s risk of disease .

Context: What was the profile of students at schools attended by Hispanic students over the years?
Summary: Nationally , the typical Hispanic student in 2006 - 07 attended a school that was 55 % Hispanic , up from 52 % Hispanic in 1993 - 94 .

Context: What is the opinion about gene editing among the American?
Summary: Specifically , a majority of Americans ( 58 % ) believe gene editing will very likely lead to increased inequality because it will only be available to the wealthy . Some 54 % of Americans anticipate a slippery slope , saying it ’s very likely that “ even if gene editing is used appropriately in some cases , others will use these techniques in ways that are morally unacceptable . ” And , 46 % expect it is very likely that gene editing techniques will be used before we fully understand how they affect people ’s health

Context: Describe some worries that parents have about their children online?
Summary: even as most parents are confident they can educate their child about proper online conduct , notable shares are concerned about the types of negative experiences their teen might encounter online . Roughly six - in - ten parents say they worry at least somewhat about their teen being harassed or bullied online ( 59 % ) or sending or receiving explicit images ( 57 % ) . These parental concerns tend to vary by race and ethnicity , as well as by a child ’s gender . Among parents , whites and Hispanics are more likely than blacks to say they worry about their teen being cyberbullied . Hispanic parents also are more inclined than black parents to say they worry about their child exchanging explicit images . At the same time , parents of teen girls are somewhat more likely than those with a teenage boy to say they worry about their teen being bullied online ( 64 % vs. 54 % ) or exchanging explicit images ( 64 % vs. 51 % ) .

Context: What is the opinion of UK about Americans and Germans  foreign policy?
Summary: In the U.S. , people are most likely to name the UK ( 36 % ) as the most important foreign policy partner for the U.S. Only about one - in - ten ( 13 % ) name Germany , ranking it fifth on Americans ’ list

Context: What has been the change since 1998 in consumer confidence?
Summary: Since 1998 , roughly 20 % of the change in consumer confidence can be attributed to movement in the stock market .

Context: What's the asylum seekers' proportion?
Summary: Of the referred cases in 2017 , asylum seekers from Haiti ( 8,286 ) had the most applications , followed by Nigeria ( 5,575 ) and Turkey ( 2,197 ) . No country saw a bigger increase in referred applications from 2016 to 2017 than Haiti , which had only 631 referred applications in 2016 . As a result , Haiti accounted for almost a third ( 32 % ) of Canada ’s overall increase in referred asylum claims in 2017

Context: How do GOP Muslims see Trump?
Summary: Republican Muslims are less likely than Democrats to see the Republican Party generally , and President Trump specifically , as unfriendly toward Muslim Americans . Still , sizable shares see their own party – and Trump – as unfriendly . In the 2017 survey , around half of GOP Muslims ( 52 % ) said Trump is unfriendly toward U.S. Muslims and about a third ( 34 % ) said the same about the GOP in general .

Context: What opinion do the public have about the majority of Czechs on the shift from one-party to multi-party system in the 1990s?
Summary: most Czechs ( 80 % ) approved of the change from a one - party to a multiparty system that took place in the early 1990s .

Context: What do Pakistanis say about their governments efforts towards extremists?
Summary: in the spring of 2015 , Pakistanis were confident that the government was making progress in the fight against extremists . A 56 % majority said that government was making progress , with only 7 % saying the Islamabad was losing ground and 12 % saying things were about the same as in the past . As is typical of Pakistani public opinion , a quarter did not offer an opinion .

Context: Compare the naturalisation rates of Mexican-born immigrants and non-Mexican immigrants.
Summary: Their rate of naturalization—36%—is only half that of legal immigrants from all other countries combined .

Context: Write some information about ease of obtaining abortions based on distance of clinics?
Summary: People who live in places with abortion clinics nearby are much more likely to say it is easy for someone in their area to obtain an abortion than those who live further away . Three - quarters of those within 5 miles of an abortion clinic say it is at least somewhat easy for someone to obtain an abortion in their area , while 47 % of those who live 50 miles away from the nearest clinic say this . This pattern is similar among both Democrats and Republicans .

Context: Describe information about person who do better job between Trump and Clinton?
Summary: Other issues are seen as more important by backers of one of the candidates : Trump supporters are more likely than Clinton supporters to say immigration is very important to their vote ( 79 % vs. 65 % ) , though the importance of this issue across - the - board is substantially higher today than it was in 2008 or 2012 . Conversely , though nearly eight - in - ten ( 79 % ) Clinton supporters view the treatment of racial and ethnic minorities as a very important issue to their vote , only 42 % of Trump backers say the same . And while more than half of Clinton supporters ( 54 % ) say the treatment of gay , lesbian and transgender people is very important , just a quarter of Trump supporters agree . Clinton is viewed as better able than Trump to handle several issues , including dealing with race relations ( 66 % to 26 % over Trump ) , better reflecting people ’s views on abortion , making wise decisions on foreign policy , dealing with health care and selecting Supreme Court justices . Yet voters are divided over which candidate can better handle the economy and terrorism – the two issues that rank at the top of voters ’ agenda . Trump has a wide edge over Clinton as being better able to reduce the influence of lobbyists and special interests in Washington ( 50 % to 30 % ) .

Context: What do you know about the religious intolerance level during the period from 2002 to 2008?
Summary: in 2002 roughly three - in - four Lebanese Muslims ( 74 % ) said such attacks could often or sometimes be justified ; today , 32 % take this view

Context: Describe some information about Labor unions and business corporations viewed favorably?
Summary: With President Donald Trump ’s labor secretary nominee set to appear before the Senate next week , the public has broadly positive views of both labor unions and business corporations . About six - in - ten adults today have a favorable view of labor unions ( 60 % ) and business corporations ( 56 % ) , according to a new Pew Research Center survey . Views of both have grown more positive since March 2015 , when roughly half of adults ( 48 % ) expressed a favorable view of each .

Context: What are trends in the Economic News people are receiving?
Summary: About half of the public ( 54 % ) says they are hearing a mix of good and bad news about the economy these days , while 41 % say they are hearing mostly bad news .

Context: What is the opinion of the public about the impact of the decline in union membership on the country?
Summary: The public expresses mixed views of the impact of the long - term decline in union membership on the country : 45 % say this has been mostly a bad thing , while 43 % see it as mostly a good thing .

Context: What is the understanding of Hispanics and their belief that being Hispanics is part of their racial backgrounds? What does this suggest in relation to U.S. official definitions of race?
Summary: A new Pew Research Center survey of multiracial Americans finds that , for two - thirds of Hispanics , their Hispanic background is a part of their racial background – not something separate . This suggests that Hispanics have a unique view of race that does n’t necessarily fit within the official U.S. definitions

Context: What is the opinion of people all over the world about a typical day ?
Summary: A median of nearly two - thirds ( 65 % ) across 44 countries surveyed in spring 2014 responded that they were having a typical day . Only around a quarter ( 27 % ) said their day was going particularly well , and not even one - in - ten ( 7 % ) admitted their day was going poorly

Context: Compare the number of primaries for the Democratic and Republican parties in 2016.
Summary: Democrats will vote in a record 41 state and territorial primaries this year . Republicans will hold a total of 39 primaries .
