Summary: half of Ukrainians 51 % opposed their country ’s admission to NATO while only 28 % favored such a step .

And increasing percentages describe him as a strong leader , able to get things done and as someone who stands up for his beliefs .

Context: Is it possible to COVID-19 official statistics might be fragile due to the non-diagnosticated cases?

Context: What opinion do Democrats and Democratic leaners have about the income pattern?
Summary: Among Democrats and Democratic leaners , the income pattern in views is the reverse : Those with higher incomes are more likely than those with lower incomes to say tax cuts for large businesses and corporations would hurt the economy . About six - in - ten Democrats with incomes of $ 75,000 a year or more ( 61 % ) think lowering taxes on corporations would hurt the economy , compared with 44 % of those earning $ 30,000 a year or less . While Democrats overall think lower taxes on large businesses and corporations would make the tax system less fair , this view is more widely held among those earning $ 75,000 a year or more ( 76 % ) and those earning between $ 30,000 and $ 74,999 ( 61 % ) than among those with household incomes of less than $ 30,000 ( 45 % ) .

Summary: The president ’s approval ratings slid over time to historic lows .

Summary: Global ratings for the U.S. , declined sharply in the first year of the Trump administration : A median of 49 % see the U.S. in a positive light , while 39 % offer an unfavorable view .

Context: How did the public react to Supreme Court nominees' announcements?
Summary: A few weeks after President Donald Trump ’s announcement of Neil Gorsuch as his nominee to the Supreme Court , 44 % of Americans say they favor the Senate confirming him to the high court , while 32 % are opposed ; roughly a quarter ( 24 % ) offer no opinion . Overall views of Gorsuch ’s nomination are similar to views of Barack Obama ’s choice of Merrick Garland nearly a year ago . Last March , 46 % favored Senate confirmation of Garland , 30 % were opposed and 24 % had no opinion .

Context: How CNN's credibility ratings has changed compared to fox News channel?
Summary: CNN ’s once dominant credibility ratings have slumped in recent years . Context: Describe the trend among Americans who think the police do an excellent or good job of protecting people?
Summary: A 58 % majority of Americans say police around the country do an excellent or good job of protecting people from crime , which is little changed from the share who said this four years ago ( 62 % ) .

Context: Explain how Egyptians' confidence level in Obama has changed.

Summary: On average , men were aware of 7 % fewer stressful events among their closest social ties .

Context: Describe some information about U.S. and China named as best examples of a developed economy?

Summary: since 2011 , it is still the case that fewer adults were currently married in 2012 ( 50.5 % ) than in 2011 ( 50.8 % ) .

Summary: Among Democrats and independents who lean to the Democratic Party , 78 % say climate change should be a top priority , up 22 percentage points since 2016 .

Context: Describe tech use among adults of ages 65 and older?
Summary: Seniors ages 65 to 69 are about twice as likely as those ages 80 and older to say they ever go online ( 82 % vs. 44 % ) or have broadband at home ( 66 % vs. 28 % ) , and they are roughly four times as likely to say they own smartphones ( 59 % vs. 17 % ) .

Context: Compare the birth rate among women in the US.
Summary: While the birth rate has declined among both U.S.-born and foreign - born women , immigrant women saw the biggest decline , from 90.7 births per 1,000 women in 2000 down to 77.4 in 2017 . Among U.S.-born women , the birth rate dropped from 60.9 to 56.2 .

Context: What are some perspectives about personal choices when it comes to medical treatment?
Summary: Nearly two - thirds of whites ( 65 % ) say they would stop their medical treatment if they had an incurable disease and were suffering a great deal of pain ; by contrast , 61 % of blacks and 55 % of Hispanics say they would tell their doctors to do everything possible to save their lives in these circumstances .

Context: What percentage of voters aged 30 to 49 follow political figures on social media?
Summary: Some 21 % of voters ages 30 - 49 follow political figures on social media , a more than three - fold increase from the previous midterm cycle

Context: What was the trend among the Tea Party regarding support for Romney in the 2012 elections?
Summary: 20 % likely Republican primary voters who agree with the Tea Party say Romney is their top choice for the GOP nomination . Another 40 % say if their preferred candidate were not in the race there is a chance they could vote for the former Massachusetts governor . 31 % likely Republican primary voters who agree with the Tea Party say there is no chance they would vote for Romney .

Context: What is the situation on the age group that is most likely to share text messages with others watching the same program?
Summary: those ages 18 - 24 stand out even compared with those just a few years older

Context: What portion is likely to express a favorable opinion of labor unions as far as age is concerned?
Summary: Young adults continue to be more likely than older people to express a favorable opinion of labor unions . A 68 % majority of those ages 18 to 29 hold a positive view of unions , compared with only about half ( 51 % ) of those 50 and older . Adults younger than 30 also are somewhat less likely to view businesses favorably : Fewer than half ( 46 % ) hold a favorable opinion of business corporations , while 47 % hold an unfavorable view . By contrast , older Americans are more likely to be positive than negative in their views . Adults under 30 are the only age group in which a larger share has a favorable view of labor unions than of business corporations .

Context: What opinion do Bogue respondeents have about the survey?
Summary: While 78 % of bogus respondents reported approving of President Donald Trump ’s job performance , their approval rating of the 2010 health care law , also known as Obamacare , was even higher , at 84 % .

Context: What is the expected trend in the Muslim population share in the U.S.?
Summary: Muslims made up about 1 % of the total U.S. population , and we estimate that that share will double by 2050 .

Context: Describe the Twitter and Facebook users interest in politics ?
Summary: Four - in - ten ( 41 % ) Twitter users who are very interested in politics say that at least half of the posts that they see are political . This compares with about a quarter ( 26 % ) of highly politically - interested Facebook users who say the same

Context: Describe the proportion of adult Lebanese who said they were pessimistic about the future of their country's political system?
Summary: Around two - thirds or more of Lebanese adults said they are pessimistic about the future of their country ’s political system ( 76 % )

Context: What percentage of Americans would likely vote for a presidential candidate that is an atheist?
Summary: about half ( 53 % ) of Americans said they would be less likely to support an atheist .

Context: What is the opinion of north americans about the Freedom Caucus?
Summary: Americans who have heard of the House Freedom Caucus are more likely to have negative than positive views of it . Overall , 36 % of these adults view the group favorably and 48 % view it unfavorably , and opinions vary sharply by political affiliation .

Context: What are the public's top priorities for the new president?
Summary: Roughly three - quarters say that defending the country from terrorism ( 76 % ) and strengthening the economy ( 73 % ) should be top priorities for Congress and the new president . And two - thirds or more prioritize improving the educational system ( 69 % ) , improving the job situation ( 68 % ) and reducing health care costs ( 66 % ) .

Context: Where are the Muslims that aren't most likely to say religion is very important in their lives?
Summary: Muslims in Lebanon are the least likely to say religion is very important in their life — just over half ( 54 % ) say religion is very important

Context: What opinion do Japanese people have about how the country is doing?
Summary: Just one - in - five are satisfied with the way things are going in Japan , while nearly eight - in - ten ( 78 % ) are dissatisfied The degree of dissatisfaction is up slightly from last year ( 72 % ) .

Context: Describe the increase in the household of Generation X.
Summary: Gen X households also experienced a stronger recovery in financial assets than Boomer and Silent households . The median financial assets of Gen X households nearly doubled from 2010 ( $ 11,300 ) to 2016 ( $ 21,600 ) .

Context: What are the views of postgraduates and college graduates on why a person is rich or poor?
Summary: Those with postgraduate degrees are more likely to say that having more advantages in life has more to do with why a person is rich ( 52 % ) than they are to say hard work has more to do with it ( 34 % ) . When it comes to the reasons why a person is poor , majorities of postgraduates ( 62 % ) and college graduates ( 59 % ) say circumstances are generally to blame . Most of those with some college experience ( 54 % ) also take this view .

Context: How was the U.S military presence in some countries in 2016?
Summary: The five countries with the largest active - duty U.S. military presence in 2016 were Japan ( 38,818 ) , Germany ( 34,602 ) , South Korea ( 24,189 ) , Italy ( 12,088 ) and Afghanistan ( 9,023 ) .

Context: What is the opinion of voters regarding their ability to make an impact in their community ?
Summary: About eight - in - ten consistent voters ( 81 % ) said individual votes can make a difference and influence an election . A somewhat smaller majority ( 69 % ) of those who missed the 2014 midterm but turned out in 2012 and 2016 said the same . By contrast , fewer than half nonvoters ( 42 % ) – who did not cast ballots in 2012 , 2014 or 2016 – said a person ’s vote can make a difference .

Context: Describe some information about both partisans and learners views of the opposing party have eased?
Summary: Currently , 87 % of those who identify with the Republican Party view the Democratic Party unfavorably ; Republican - leaning independents are almost as likely to view the Democratic Party negatively ( 81 % unfavorable ) Opinions among Democrats and Democratic leaners are nearly the mirror image : 88 % of Democrats and 84 % of Democratic leaners view the GOP unfavorably .

Context: What are opinions about the management of children's schedules and activities by parents who both work full-time ?
Summary: Some 54 % of parents in households with two full - time working parents say the mother does more to manage the children ’s schedule and activities , while 39 % say this task is shared equally and 6 % say the father does more . And 47 % say the mother takes on more when their children fall ill , equal to the share saying they split this duty equally ; just 6 % say the father does more of this .

Context: What is the trend among Americans towards US cellphone and smartphone brands in 2013?
Summary: 25 % of all U.S. cellphone owners own an iPhone .

Context: What are people's thoughts regarding the Anna Nicole Smith incidence and the role of press?
Summary: a sizable minority ( 11 % ) followed Smith ’s death more closely than any of last week ’s other top stories The death of Anna Nicole Smith , which set off a classic media feeding frenzy , may be an instance where press coverage exceeded public demand Eleven percent of the public said Smith ’s death was the news story they followed most closely last week ; 9 % of the week ’s news coverage was devoted to this topic But because the death occurred mid - week , the full extent of news coverage is not accurately captured by that 9 % figure

Context: Describe the proportion of the public following news related to Iraq war in the week of Jan 28 - Feb 3.
Summary: 28 % of the public followed news about the Iraq war very closely . Iraq was the most closely followed story for 13 % of the public .

Context: Explain the social media impacts on getting the people-in for voting?
Summary: Social media platforms have also become a notable venue for people to try to convince their friends to vote . More broadly , registered voters have used a variety of methods to talk to others about voting . Below are the ways that people are hearing from their family and friends , encouraging them to vote . There is no overall partisan tilt to one candidate or the other when it comes to the “ go vote ” messages people are getting from their friends and family through various channels . Equal shares of registered voters were encouraged by their friends to vote for each candidate in each kind of communication :

Context: What news are regularly seen on Facebook?
Summary: While Facebook news consumers say they see regularly news about a range of different topics , entertainment news seems to stand out : Almost three - quarters ( 73 % ) said they regularly saw entertainment news on the site . The next most commonly cited topics : community news ( 65 % ) and sports ( 57 % ) .

Context: What is the trend of summer employment rate in 2014 among teens from different races?
Summary: White teens are much more likely to work over the summer than teens of other races and ethnicities . Last year , for example , the summer employment rate for 16- to 19 - year - old whites was 34.0 % , versus 19.3 % for blacks , 23.0 % for Asians and 25.0 % for Hispanics ( who can be of any race ) .

Context: Describe the public's interest in midterm elections in 2014.
Summary: Midterm elections rarely excite the general public , but 2014 is shaping up to be an especially underwhelming cycle for many Americans . With about a month remaining in the congressional races , 15 % are very closely following news about the midterms .

Context: What are the major motives for people to accept immigrants?
Summary: Even though many people in the nations surveyed say they want less immigration , there is considerable support for accepting both refugees who flee violence ( a median of 77 % ) . Majorities in eight of 10 European countries favor taking in refugees , with roughly eight - in - ten or more in Spain , the Netherlands , Germany , Sweden and France expressing this view . Hungarians have the lowest support for this policy , with about a third ( 32 % ) who believe refugees should be allowed into the country .

Context: How does the public feel about reelecting incumbents?
Summary: 38 % of voters who say they want their own representative to be defeated .

Context: Describe partisan favorability evaluation of China compared to 2018.
Summary: Seven - in - ten Republicans and Republican leaners have an unfavorable opinion of China today , up from 51 % in 2018 . Among Democrats and Democratic leaners , unfavorable opinion increased somewhat less over the same period , from 47 % to 59 % .

Context: How are coverage and public interest on popular news?
Summary: Three - in - ten Americans followed news about the shootings at Fort Hood more closely than any other news story last week news coverage of the Fort Hood rampage accounted for 15 % of the overall weekly newshole . Other leading stories – tracked over the full course of the week – such as health care reform and the off - year elections filled a somewhat smaller percentage of the newshole ( 8 % and 13 % , respectively ) .

Context: What are trends in voters giving a lot of thought to the election?
Summary: In the new survey , 55 % of voters say they have given a lot of thought to the election , which is about the same as in 2006 ( 54 % ) , but much higher than levels in the three previous midterms .

Context: What is distribution of Black eligible voters in US states?
Summary: In Georgia , Arizona , Pennsylvania , Michigan and Wisconsin , a large majority of Black eligible voters live in each state ’s metro area .

Context: Describe how immigrants arrival from Mexico and the three Central American nations changed from 2011 ?
Summary: about 115,000 new immigrants arrived from the Northern Triangle in 2014 , double the 60,000 who entered the U.S. three years earlier . Meanwhile , the number of new arrivals from Mexico declined slightly from 175,000 in 2011 to 165,000 in 2014

Context: Discuss the various factors affecting the 2008 campaign and public's interest towards it.
Summary: According to the Project for Excellence in Journalism ’s ( PEJ ) News Coverage Index , national cable TV news outlets devoted 74 % of their coverage last week to the campaign and only 4 % to the Chinese earthquake . By contrast , network TV news and national newspapers split their coverage about equally between these two stories While cable networks devoted 74 % of their coverage to the campaign , only 20 % of the public listed the campaign as the single news story they followed most closely .

Context: Describe the main reasons why Mexicans did not naturalize in the U.S.?
Summary: Asked why they had n’t yet naturalized , the Center ’s 2015 survey found that 35 % of Mexican and 23 % of other Latino immigrants with green cards identified personal barriers , such as a lack of English proficiency . Another common reason given was a lack of interest or just having not applied yet About a third ( 31 % ) of Mexican lawful immigrants said this , while only 16 % of non - Mexican Latino immigrants said the same . An additional 13 % of Mexican and 19 % of non - Mexican lawful immigrants identified financial and administrative barriers , mainly the cost of naturalization .

Context: How republicans view Barack and Michelle Obama?
Summary: Fully 81 % of Republicans feel very coldly toward Barack Obama . Nearly six - in - ten Republicans ( 59 % ) give very cold ratings to Michelle Obama .

Context: Describe the views of people who disapprove of Trump.
Summary: Among those who disapprove of Trump , 65 % of self - identified Democrats say they do n’t think those with a different view of Trump share their other values and goals . Among those who disapprove of Trump and lean toward the Democratic Party ( but do n’t identify with it ) , views are more mixed : 47 % think those with a different view of Trump probably share many of their other values and goals , while 52 % think they probably do not

Context: Comment on the non-users who would like to get a mobile phone in the future?
Summary: A median of 47 % of non - users say they would like to have a mobile phone . That sentiment among non - users ranges from 86 % of non - users in Venezuela to 9 % in Lebanon .

Context: What is the percentage of adults who experienced the form of harassment online and how do they think about them?
Summary: Some 41 % of adults have experienced some form of online harassment

Context: Describe the support for the Euro.
Summary: the euro remains in public favor . More than six - in - ten people want to keep the euro as their currency in Greece ( 69 % ) , Spain ( 67 % ) , Germany ( 66 % ) , Italy ( 64 % ) and France ( 63 % ) .

Context: Discuss English speaking trends among Hispanic Millennials?
Summary: About three - quarters of Hispanic Millennials are proficient English speakers – that is , they either speak only English at home ( 28 % ) or speak a language other than English at home , but speak English “ very well ” ( 48 % ) .    Some 19 % of Hispanic Millennials speak English less than very well and just 5 % do not speak English at all .

Context: What are the Mexicans' opinions about Peña Nieto's handling of specific national issues?
Summary: Peña Nieto gets poor marks for the way he has handled specific issues , including some major planks of his reform agenda . A majority ( 63 % ) also disapproves of Peña Nieto ’s handling of police reform . A 63 % majority disapproves of the way Peña Nieto has pursued the fight against organized crime and drug trafficking in Mexico , while over half disapprove of his handling of relations with the U.S. and the issue of education .

Context: What is the situation on percentage of women using Facebook and living with a minor at home compared to men?
Summary: Some 79 % of moms use Facebook , compared with 61 % of all women and 57 % of men with a minor child living at home

Context: How was economic news followed after reports of the US budget deficit?
Summary: Amid reports about a projected $ 1.75 trillion federal budget deficit and a grim week on Wall Street , 56 % of Americans say they paid very close attention to news about the economy , and 34 % say it was the news they followed most closely .

Context: What is the opinion of people about performance of press ?
Summary: . Fully 66 % say news stories often are inaccurate , 77 % think that news organizations tend to favor one side , and 80 % say news organizations are often influenced by powerful people and organizations .

Context: Describe how suspected bots are acting in legacy sites and digital native sites.
Summary: Suspected bots shared 60 % of tweeted links to legacy sites , about on par with the 59 % of tweeted links to digital native sites

Context: Describe the distribution of Dominicans of different religious affiliations.
Summary: about six - in - ten Dominican adults ( 59 % ) identify themselves as Catholic . Roughly two - in - ten ( 21 % ) Dominicans are Protestant . Some 16 % of Dominican adults are religiously unaffiliated .

Context: What opinion do the majority of Ukrainians have about the direction of their country?
Summary: Roughly nine - in - ten ( 88 % ) Ukrainians are dissatisfied with the way things are going in their country . A roughly equal percentage ( 91 % ) describes the current economic situation in Ukraine as somewhat or very bad , with a majority ( 59 % ) saying very bad .

Context: What is confidence of Clinton supporters of Clinton winning the election?
Summary: Fully 92 % of registered voters who support Clinton for president expect her to win .

Context: What is the trend in US youth depression?
Summary: In 2016 , 12.8 % of youths ages 12 to 17 had experienced a major depressive episode in the past year , up from 8 % as recently as 2010 . For 9 % of youths in 2016 , their depression caused severe impairment . Fewer than half of youths with major depression said they ’d been treated for it in the past year .

Context: How was the public interest on the news about the elections and cruise ship accident?
Summary: The crash of a cruise ship and the latest developments in the 2012 presidential campaign topped the public ’s news interests last week . About a quarter ( 26 % ) say they followed news about the cruise ship accident more closely than any other news . A comparable percentage ( 23 % ) say they followed news about candidates for the 2012 presidential election most closely .

Context: How has the American public view on China evolved?
Summary: The share of Americans with an unfavorable view of China reached a 14 - year high amid a protracted trade dispute between the two countries . Six - in - ten U.S. adults have a negative opinion of China , up from 47 % in 2018 and the highest share since 2005 .

Context: What are details about Majority of Filipinos are satisfied with the direction of the country?
Summary: A 57 % majority say they are satisfied with the way things are going in their country , up from 36 % three years ago . Moreover , 78 % believe that the economic situation in the Philippines is good , while only 20 % say the economy is in bad shape .

Context: How much are the Americans talking about gas prices?
Summary: Three - quarters say that it is a subject that comes up “ frequently ” in conversations .

Context: What are the partisan views on police filling the roles of enforcers and protectors?
Summary: Partisans differ in the role they see police performing . about a third of Democrats ( 31 % ) and independents ( 33 % ) say they see police in this country more as enforcers than protectors , roughly double the share of Republicans who say this ( 17 % ) . Republicans , for their part , are more likely to say police in this country fill both of these roles equally ( 67 % ) compared with Democrats ( 52 % ) and independents ( 53 % ) .

Context: How do people think Islamism influences politics in their country?
Summary: In Indonesia , about nine - in - ten Muslims ( 91 % ) either say that their religion plays a large role in politics and that this is a good thing or that Islam plays a small role and that this is a bad thing . Similarly , at least three - quarters of Muslims in Egypt ( 85 % ) , Nigeria ( 82 % ) and Jordan ( 76 % ) consider Islamic influence over political life to be a positive thing for their country , as do 69 % of Muslims in Pakistan and 58 % in Lebanon . Only in Turkey are opinions about the role of Islam in political life more mixed . About four - in - ten ( 38 % ) Turkish Muslims say Islam plays a large role and embrace its influence in their country ’s politics or say it is bad that Islam plays only a small role ; about three - in - ten ( 31 % ) say Islam ’s influence is negative .

Context: What is the opinion of Indians about people leaving for jobs in other countries?
Summary: When asked if people leaving for jobs in other countries posed a problem for India , more than six - in - ten ( 64 % ) said this type of emigration was a problem .

Context: What is the Indians view about current laws and law enforcements in dealing with rape cases ?
Summary: Fewer than one - in - ten Indians rate the current laws as “ about right ” in dealing with cases of rape ( 7 % ) . And only 6 % of the public says that the police investigate these cases adequately . Meanwhile , 18 % think that laws on rape are too tough , while 15 % hold this view about law enforcement

Context: Describe the proportion of Americans who say they understand 'very much' of the current laws and regulations in place to protect the privacy of their data?
Summary: Just 3 % of U.S. adults say they have “ a lot ” of understanding of the current laws and regulations in place to protect their data privacy

Context: How has the usage of Spanish in Hispanic households changed?
Summary: a record 35 million Hispanics ages 5 and older speak Spanish ( at home ) , up from 25 million in 2000 and 10 million in 1980 .

Context: Describe the view of Americans towards Obama's approach in environmental matters.
Summary: The environment is the only one of nine issues tested in a post - election poll where Obama enjoys a clear edge , with Americans favoring his approach to the subject over that of the Republicans by a 35 % to 20 % margin . About four - in - ten ( 41 % ) see no difference between the two .

Context: How's electronics recycling seen among the public?
Summary: The Pew Research Center survey found that 59 % of the public believes that “ most types of items ” can be recycled in their community ; another 26 % characterize their options as “ some , ” and 13 % say only a few types of items can be recycled where they live . And the people who live in places that strongly encourage recycling also are more likely to say that most types of items can be recycled there . About half ( 48 % ) of adults in the Pew Research Center survey say their community has services for recycling electronic devices , though about a third ( 34 % ) say they are n’t sure .

Context: Describe public assessments of the state of the nation in July 2011.
Summary: in July 2011 , just 17 % were satisfied , while 79 % were dissatisfied .

Context: How has Russian views of Western powers changed?
Summary: Russians have soured considerably on major Western powers in just the past few years . Favorable views of the U.S. , Germany , the EU and NATO have dropped by 25 percentage points or more since 2011 .

Context: Explain about smartphones attitudes among various age groups?
Summary: Asked if they feel that their phone represents “ freedom ” or “ a leash , ” 82 % of smartphone - owning seniors described their phone as freeing , compared with 64 % of those ages 18 to 29 . By contrast , 36 % of adult smartphone owners under the age of 30 described their phone as a leash ,

Context: How are American newsroom employees divided between US regions?
Summary: Newsroom employees are more likely than all U.S. workers to live in the Northeast . Roughly a quarter ( 24 % ) of all newsroom employees work in this region A third of newsroom employees live in the South About the same share of newsroom employees and all workers live in the West ( 22 % vs. 23 % ) and Midwest ( 20 % vs. 22 % )

Context: Comment on the birth rates of U.S born women ages 15 to 44.
Summary: The birth rate dipped in 2011 to the lowest ever recorded . The birth rate for U.S.-born women decreased 6 % during these years .

Context: Describe the Muslim population in the U.S.?
Summary: The Muslim population in the United States is younger than the U.S. population at large . In fact , while Millennials make up 32 % of all U.S. adults , they account for roughly half of American Muslim adults ( 52 % ) .

Context: What is the public's recent opinion now about voting for a black candidate?
Summary: Most recently , in 2003 , 92 % said they would vote for a black candidate for president while just 6 % said they would not .

Context: What is the opinion of the majority of the public on whose fault is it for the middle class's difficulties?
Summary: Congress gets the most votes , with 62 % assigning it “ a lot ” of the blame .

Context: Explain Venezuelans opinions about their country economy among ages.
Summary: Since Maduro took office in 2013 , Venezuelans ’ evaluations of their national economy have worsened . Today , 83 % say the current economic situation in Venezuela is bad , including 60 % who say that it ’s very bad . Those ages 18 to 29 ( 86 % ) are slightly more likely than people 50 and older to say the economy is in poor shape ( 75 % ) . Views of the national economy are also heavily colored by partisanship . Whereas about six - in - ten PSUV supporters say the economy is in poor shape ( 59 % ) , nine - in - ten non - PSUV supporters say the same .

Context: What is the opinion of who have no religious affiliation ?
Summary: Respondents who have no religious affiliation are the most likely to think that science and religion , in general , are often in conflict ,  with 76 % expressing this view .    But just one - in - six religiously unaffiliated adults ( 16 % ) say their own religious beliefs conflict with science . ( Those who are religiously unaffiliated often have supernatural beliefs and spiritual practices , even though they say they do not feel connected to a particular religion . Only about a third of the unaffiliated say they are atheist or agnostic ; most describe their religion as “ nothing in particular . ” )

Context: How do the public and police view the police-black encounters?
Summary: while 67 % of officers say the deaths of blacks in recent encounters with police are isolated incidents , less than half of the public ( 39 % ) shares this view .

Context: What is the opinion of the vast majority of people on what is the best long-term investment they can make?
Summary: eight out of 10 people agreed that buying a home was the best long - term investment a person can make

Context: What are trends in views of the health care law?
Summary: By roughly the same margin ( 37 % to 30 % ) , more say that , looking ahead , the health care law will have a mostly negative than a mostly positive personal impact , while 30 % say it will not have much of an effect . This is little changed over the last few years .

Context: Comment on the public's satisfaction with the country's direction in Pakistan.
Summary: 91 % of the public thinks the country is on the wrong track .

Context: What do people think about the local news outlets financially?
Summary: about seven - in - ten Americans ( 71 % ) believe their local news media organizations are doing well financially . This belief persists even though only 14 % of U.S. adults say they personally have paid for local news within the past year , whether through subscriptions , donations or memberships . When asked why they do n’t pay for local news , around half of non - payers ( 49 % ) point to the widespread availability of free content .

Context: Tell some details about twitter usage among legislators across the surveyed countries?
Summary: Most legislators across these five countries maintain Twitter accounts : 73 % tweeted at least once in the first six months of 2019 .

Context: What caused ratings for Russia in the U.S. to drop?
Summary: Ratings for Russia in both the U.S. and Germany have fallen sharply since 2011 , when massive protests swept across Russia after accusations of ballot - rigging in the December parliamentary elections . They reached a low point in 2014 after the annexation of Crimea ( 19 % favorable in both countries ) .

Context: What Clinton voters think about terrorism security in the U.S.?
Summary: Voters who back Clinton were divided , While 37 % thought security from terrorism in the U.S. has gotten better since 2008 , about as many ( 41 % ) said it has stayed about the same , and 22 % thought it has gotten worse .

Context: Compare the impact of social media among workers of different ages.
Summary: Younger workers are more likely than their older counterparts to say they have discovered information about a colleague on social media that lowered their professional opinion of them – but also are more likely than older workers to have found information that improved their professional opinion of a colleague . Some 23 % of workers ages 18 to 29 report that they have discovered information on social media that improved their professional opinion of a colleague . By comparison , just 12 % of workers ages 30 to 49 and 9 % of workers ages 50 to 64 have experienced this . Similarly , 29 % of these younger workers have discovered information that lowered their professional opinion of a colleague : 16 % of those ages 30 to 49 and 6 % of those ages 50 to 64 indicate that this has happened to them .

Context: How do most American and Canadian audiences view China?
Summary: Negative views of China predominate in both the United States and Canada , where 60 % and 67 % respectively see the country unfavorably .

Context: How do Smartphone Owners view their devices?
Summary: Some 46 % of smartphone owners said their smartphone is something “ they could n’t live without , ” compared with 54 % who said in a 2014 Pew Research Center survey that their phone is “ not always needed . ” . In addition to being essential for many , smartphone owners are much more likely to have positive views of these devices . For instance , they are much more likely to say smartphones are more helpful than annoying , represent freedom rather than represent a leash , enable connecting rather than being distracting and are worth the cost rather than being a financial burden .

Context: What was the response of public towards the China earthquake incidence?
Summary: About one - in - five Americans ( 22 % ) say they followed news about the earthquake in China more closely than any other story last week , which is about the same percentage citing the presidential campaign as their top story ( 20 % )

Context: Describe the rates of political participation of Americans?
Summary: Attending a political campaign event or speech is the second most common type of participation among those surveyed – a median of 33 % have done this at least once . Fewer people report participating in volunteer organizations ( a median of 27 % ) , posting comments on political issues online ( 17 % ) , participating in an organized protest ( 14 % ) or donating money to a social or political organization ( 12 % ) .

Context: Describe the Americans expectations regard China's global influence to wane after the pandemic?
Summary: Half of Americans expect China ’s global influence to wane after the pandemic China ’s response to the virus has been met with disapproval by many Americans , half of whom believe the country ’s international reputation will take a hit as a result of the virus . About a third ( 31 % ) of Americans think China ’s influence will remain the same , and roughly a fifth ( 17 % ) expect it will grow .

Context: What are the details about health main care reasons reform bills?
Summary: Among supporters of the health care bills , 86 % say expanding health coverage to the uninsured is a major reason for their support and 84 % cite assuring that no one is denied coverage because they have pre - existing conditions as a major reason . About seven - in - ten ( 72 % ) say the current system costs too much and 64 % say insurance companies doing a bad job are major reasons for their support .

Context: How are Americans seeing undocumented immigrants?
Summary: About seven - in - ten Americans ( 71 % ) say that undocumented immigrants living in the United States mostly fill jobs that American citizens do not want . Nearly as many ( 65 % ) say undocumented immigrants are not more likely than U.S. citizens to commit serious crimes

Context: What is the opinion of the public about Government spending on aid to world's needy ?
Summary: as many say that funding for aid to the needy overseas should either be increased ( 21 % ) , or kept the same ( 28 % ) , as decreased ( 48 % ) .

Context: What is the trend in immigration flow from Mexico to U.S. since 1850 ?
Summary: The largest wave of immigration in history from a single country to the United States has come to a standstill . After four decades that brought 12 million current immigrants the net migration flow from Mexico to the United States has stopped and may have reversed , according to a new analysis of government data from both countries by the Pew Hispanic Center .

Context: What is the public's top priority for congress?
Summary: Defending against terrorism continues to rank among the public ’s leading priorities for the president and Congress , with nearly three - quarters ( 73 % ) saying it is a top priority .

Context: Describe the opinion of Americans about providing contraceptives to employees?
Summary: Two - thirds ( 67 % ) of Americans say employers should be required to provide birth control to employees through their health insurance plans , even if the business owner has religious objections to contraception .

Context: Tell some information about Modern American diet in daily calories?
Summary: Americans eat more chicken and less beef than they used to . They drink less milk – especially whole milk – and eat less ice cream , but they consume way more cheese . Their diets include less sugar than in prior decades but a lot more corn - derived sweeteners . And while the average American eats the equivalent of 1.2 gallons of yogurt a year , he or she also consumes 36 pounds of cooking oils – more than three times as much as in the early 1970s .

Context: Describe some information about Clinton's approval ratings in his impeachment process?
Summary: While that initial boost faded over time , Clinton ’s approval rating in August 1998 was still a robust 62 % , where it remained for months – throughout his admission of the affair , the release of the Starr report and the opening of impeachment proceedings . Clinton ’s approval hit 71 % again in mid - December , after the House vote to impeach him .

Context: What are Americans' views about the economy?
Summary: Only about a quarter of Americans ( 23 % ) rate current economic conditions as excellent or good , while 76 % say they are only fair or poor .

Context: What is the opinion of the Chinese public about the big problems they face ?

Context: Describe the decline in the number of refugees in the U.S.

Context: What do Democrats think about the defense of their own country compared to Republicans?

Context: What opinion do the public have about the news about the war in Iraq compared with other news?
Summary: Fully 36 % of Americans paid very closely attention to events in Iraq and 35 % said this was the news story they followed more closely than any other . Another 12 % of the public listed the debate over Iraq policy as the story they followed most closely . News coverage of Iraq focused primarily on events on the ground , while the policy debate took a back seat . In previous weeks , the policy debate has received more media coverage than the situation in Iraq . However , dramatic events , including the capture of three American soldiers , altered the balance of coverage .

Context: How do people think bout accuracy of political news online?
Summary: About half ( 51 % ) say they often see political news online that is at least somewhat inaccurate – a higher proportion than those who say they see news that is almost completely made up ( 32 % ) .

Context: Describe some information about Indians' opinions about politicians?
Summary: Nearly two - thirds ( 64 % ) say most politicians are corrupt ( including 43 % who very intensely hold this view ) . Notably , nearly seven - in ten ( 69 % ) of both BJP supporters and Congress backers share the view that elected leaders are corrupt . Another 58 % voice the opinion that no matter who wins an election , things do not change very much .

Context: What is trend in the American interest in news about the presidential campaign?

Context: Which party has a better image among the public?
Summary: while the Democratic Party is viewed more favorably than it was a few months ago , the Republican Party ’s image is little changed – and remains much more negative than positive . Just 36 % have a favorable opinion of the GOP . That is largely unchanged from January ( 35 % favorable ) . Currently , 49 % say they have a favorable impression of the Democratic Party . In January , 43 % viewed the Democratic Party favorably .

Context: What is the distribution of people are concerned about Climate change in Latin America and Africa?

It ranks as the greatest threat in nearly every country in these two regions . Asians are also relatively concerned about climate change . With a median of 41 % voicing serious concern , the issue captures the top spot in half of the Asia - Pacific countries surveyed

Context: Hoe Bush's job approval rating has changed among republican?
Summary: While the decline in support transcends ideological and demographic lines , the drop among one group – moderate Republicans – has been especially steep . Among all Republicans , Bush ’s job approval rating has dropped 20 percentage points since December 2004 ( from 89 % to 69 % ) . This erosion of support has been most severe among Republicans describing themselves as moderate or liberal , where his rating has dropped 25 points from 81 % to 56 % . Conservative Republican support for Bush has also declined , but more gradually . Approval among this group was nearly unanimous ( 93 % ) following his re - election , and stands 15 points lower at 78 % today .

Context: What is the opinion of U.S. adults , Democrats and Republicans about moral quality of the president ?

Context: What's trending when it comes to U.S against ISIS?

However , Democrats are more likely than Republicans to say the military campaign has increased the chances of a terrorist attack in the U.S. ( 33 % vs. 18 % ) , while Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say the campaign against ISIS has decreased the chances of a terrorist attack ( 32 % vs. 18 % ) .

Context: What is the opinion of the public about about Republican and Democratic parties willing to cut government spending ?

Context: For the Ukrainian population, describe the public opinion on which groups benefited most from the 1991 changes.

However , just 11 % believe ordinary people have benefited .

Context: How people write positive words in associate voters?

Context: Describe the expectations of Americans on having a female leader?

Summary: About half of U.S. adults tell us they seldom ( 33 % ) or never ( 16 % ) talk about religion with people outside their family .

Context: Comment on the confidence level of European countries in the U.S. president to do the right thing regarding world affairs.
Summary: European attitudes toward Trump are strikingly negative , especially when compared with the ratings his predecessor received while in office . Looking at four European nations Pew Research Center has surveyed consistently since 2003 reveals a clear pattern regarding perceptions of American presidents . George W. Bush , whose foreign policies were broadly unpopular in Europe , got low ratings during his presidency , while the opposite was true for Barack Obama , who enjoyed strong approval in these four nations during his time in office . Following the 2016 election , confidence in the president plunged , with Trump ’s ratings resembling what Bush received near the end of his second term ( although Trump ’s numbers are up slightly in the United Kingdom this year ) .

Context: Describe American trust in climate scientists?
Summary: Some 39 % of adults trust climate scientists a lot to give full and accurate information about the causes of climate change .

Context: What is the opinion of Americans regarding Obama's speech at the Jan. 12 memorial service?
Summary: Most Americans say they heard at least a little about Obama ’s speech at the Jan. 12 memorial service at the University of Arizona ( 75 % ) . Among that group , nearly seven - in - ten ( 69 % ) say the address was either excellent or good , while 21 % rate the speech as only fair or poor . More than eight - in - ten Democrats ( 83 % ) say the speech was excellent or good . Just 11 % say it was only fair and poor . Majorities of Republicans and independents who had heard about the speech also rated it positively . Among Republicans , 56 % say the speech was either excellent or good . Two - third of independents ( 67 % ) give the speech a positive rating . Two - in - ten ( 20 % ) are more negative .

Context: Compare the proportions of enlisted personnel to all adults having a bachelor's degree?
Summary: Fewer than one - in - ten enlisted personnel ( 7 % ) have a bachelor ’s degree , compared with 19 % of all adults ages 18 to 44 .

Context: How have the number of undocumented immigrants and deportations varied over the years?
Summary: the estimated number of undocumented immigrants increased from 3 million in 1980 to 11.9 million in 2008 , a four - fold increase . The increase in the number of undocumented immigrants in the U.S. coincides with an increase in the number of deportations , or removals , done by the federal government .

Context: How is the rate of intermarriages causing the increase of Jews with one parent across the generations?
Summary: Just 6 % of Jews from the Silent Generation say they had one Jewish parent , compared with 18 % of Jewish Baby Boomers , 24 % of Generation X and nearly half ( 48 % ) of Jewish Millennials .

Context: Describe how the public followed the news about the earthquake in Haiti compared to other news?
Summary: Overall interest in news about the Haiti earthquake is on par with interest in the tsunami that struck the Indian Ocean . Fully 60 % say they followed news about the earthquake very closely ; about the same percentage ( 58 % ) said they followed news about the tsunami in the Indian Ocean very closely in January 2005 .

Context: What is the trend among Americans in reading books since 2011?
Summary: Seven - in - ten American adults ( 72 % ) have read a book within the past year . That figure has fallen from 79 % who said in 2011 they had read a book in the previous year , but is statistically in line with survey findings starting in 2012 .

Context: What is the situation of the support of different Russian leaders?
Summary: In terms of public support , Putin and Medvedev clearly stand out from other figures on Russia ’s political stage . opinions of Zyuganov , Mironov and Zhirinovsky are negative ( 52 % , 51 % and 66 % unfavorable , respectively ) .

Context: Describe the change in Americans views about the government allowing more offshore oil and gas drilling in U.S. waters.
Summary: Support for offshore drilling plummeted after 2010 , but has largely recovered since . By June , support dropped another 10 percentage points and more people opposed increased drilling ( 52 % ) than favored it ( 44 % ) . But support rose subsequent years , though not to the same heights . Last December , 56 % said they favored the government allowing more offshore drilling and 40 % opposed the practice .

Context: Describe the changes in Brazilian's views of U.S.
Summary: Nearly three - quarters of Brazilians ( 73 % ) have a favorable view of the U.S. . In our 2013 survey , 73 % of Brazilians also had a positive view of the U.S. But ratings dropped 8 percentage points in 2014 to 65 % before rebounding this year .

Context: Describe the popularity of Obama and George W. Bush is Africa.
Summary: Obama is very popular in Africa ( and so was George W. Bush ) . Obama ’s ratings in sub - Saharan Africa are overwhelmingly positive This year , we surveyed nine countries in the region , and big majorities in each nation express confidence in the American leader Of course , his predecessor was also largely popular in the region .

Context: Describe the skeptical people before election?
Summary: 86 % of those who expressed confidence in election systems across the country in October say they are confident these systems were secure . Among the 54 % who were not confident in national election systems before the midterm elections , about half ( 51 % ) now say they are confident that election systems in the United States were secure from hacking and other technological threats .

Context: How do U.S. adults view the role human astronauts in the future of the U.S. space program?
Summary: A majority of the public ( 59 % ) says astronauts are essential to include in the future of the U.S. space program , while 39 % say astronauts are not essential .

Context: What are opinions of Mexicans about big problems of the country?
Summary: Mexicans most frequently name crime ( 80 % ) and cartel - related violence ( 77 % ) as very big problems . 71 % see illegal drugs in the same light . Most ( 69 % ) also describe economic problems as a major challenge . Slightly smaller numbers place corruption ( 65 % ) and terrorism ( 62 % ) in this category , while fewer than six - in - ten ( 56 % ) characterize pollution as a very big problem .

Context: In September, how was the public interest between the policy debate and events in Iraq?
Summary: Even in mid - September , shortly after Petraeus delivered his testimony , more Americans said they were following events in Iraq very closely than said the same about Petraeus ’ report ( 31 % vs. 25 % ) .

Context: How Americans perceive the problem of the nation budget deficit?
Summary: About half of Americans ( 54 % ) view the deficit as a “ very serious ” problem for the country , while 35 % regard it as a “ somewhat serious ” problem . Very few , just 10 % , think it is not much of a problem .

Context: How is public interest in news about healthcare reform and the economy?
Summary: 31 % say the health care debate was the story they followed most closely , while 19 % say they followed reports about the U.S. economy more closely than any other story .

Context: Describe the highest state with high numbers of death row inmates and the trend in the increase.
Summary: California ’s death row has grown by nearly 100 inmates , or 14 % , since January 2006 , when it carried out its last execution , and by 28 % since 2000 , according to the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund , which tracks death row populations in all states

Context: What is the reading habit of young adults and old adults like?
Summary: As noted earlier in this report , young adults are more likely to read books than older adults . And when asked about specific reasons why they might read a range of content , these young adults are much more likely than older adults to say that they read for work or school , or to research a specific topic of interest .

Context: Describe the difference in opinions between generations about the UN?
Summary: Younger generations tend to be more favorable toward international organizations . Millennials are at least 10 percentage points more favorable toward the United Nations than are Gen Xers or Boomers .

Context: What are the views do Republican Primary Voters have about Candidate Positions?
Summary: 69 % of possible GOP primary voters say they would be more likely to support a candidate who wants to end the nuclear agreement . Just 14 % say they would be less likely to support a candidate who takes this position . Most possible GOP primary voters also say they would be more likely to vote for a candidate who wants to end federal funding for Planned Parenthood ( 56 % ) and to use U.S. ground forces to fight ISIS ( 53 % ) .

Context: What are the current thoughts on direct democracy?
Summary: A global median of 66 % say direct democracy – in which citizens vote on major issues – would be a good way to govern

Context: Compare how common is to have a smartphone between young and old people.
Summary: 92 % of 18- to 29 - year - olds say they own a smartphone , compared with 42 % of those who are ages 65 and older .

Context: What proportion of Democrats say the ideal age range for a president would be to be in their 30s?
Summary: just 6 % say it would be ideal for a president to be in their 30s .

Context: Compare the proportion of people who currently find it immoral to smoke marijuana with what people thought 15 years ago.
Summary: More recently , there has been a major shift in attitudes on whether it is immoral to smoke marijuana Currently , 32 % say that smoking marijuana is morally wrong , an 18 - point decline since 2006 ( 50 % ) .

Context: How have various countries become more important in the middle East compared to 10 years ago?
Summary: About eight - in - ten in Lebanon say that Iran is more influential in the Middle East today than it was 10 years ago . Across the region , fewer say Saudi Arabia ’s role in the region has grown . Jordan is the only country where more than half hold this view . Only a quarter or fewer in Israel and Turkey agree . Few say that Egypt plays a more important role in the Middle East now compared with 10 years ago .

Context: What is people's view of government?
Summary: But in Katrina ’s aftermath , there has been a rise in the number of Americans who view government as almost always wasteful and inefficient ­ from 47 % last December to 56 % currently

Context: What opinion do the public have about the economic news?
Summary: In other news this week , interest in the economy remained high , in spite of relatively little coverage . Fully 37 % of the public followed news about the economy very closely , down slightly from 40 % earlier this month . And 15 % listed conditions in the U.S. economy as the single news story they followed more closely than any other last week . The national news media devoted 6 % of its overall coverage to the economy .

Context: Describe the proportion of American adults who say that science has had a positive effect on society?
Summary: About seven - in - ten U.S. adults ( 73 % ) say science has had a positive effect on society

Context: How bothered are people of public marijuana use?
Summary: 62 % say that if marijuana were legal it would bother them if people used it in public ; just 33 % say this would not bother them

Context: Tell information about migrant remittances of the world by destination country?
Summary: India receives more remittances from migrants than any other country . About $ 69 billion was sent by Indian migrants to family and friends in India in 2015 .

Context: Describe how Egyptians view Abdel Fattah El-Sisi.
Summary: Sisi receives a favorable rating from 54 % of Egyptians , while 45 % view him unfavorably .

Context: Describe Americans interest in technology.
Summary: About half ( 52 % ) of employed Americans who are most interested in technology said they follow science news because it is related to their work , at least 11 % higher than any other group

Context: How are voters living in areas of high political dispute dividing their votes?
Summary: only 12 % of registered voters say they are splitting their vote between multiple political parties . About three - quarters of registered voters ( 74 % ) in these areas say they will select candidates from the same party for all major political races in their area

Context: How does the public perceive the Supreme Court?
Summary: as many Americans call the court liberal ( 26 % ) as say it is conservative ( 27 % ) . More ( 38 % ) say the current Supreme Court is “ middle of the road . ”

Context: What news on foreign attacks are Americans following closely?
Summary: About three - in - ten Americans ( 29 % ) say they had followed the news from Paris very closely , according to a new Pew Research Center survey .

Context: Describe the trend of the majority in favor of the government in reducing poverty or reducing gap of rich people and everyone else?
Summary: While a 53 % majority in this same poll favored the government doing a lot to reduce poverty , just 43 % said the government should do a lot to reduce the gap between rich people and everyone else

Context: Describe what Clinton supporters say about respecting someone who supports Trump for president ?
Summary: Nearly six - in - ten Clinton supporters ( 58 % ) say they “ have a hard time respecting someone who supports Donald Trump for president . ” Just 40 % say they have “ no trouble ” respecting someone who backs Trump .

Context: How is the trend among people from 2007 to 2010 regarding the use of email?
Summary: The median percentage that sends or receives email at least occasionally has also risen from 29 % in 2007 to 34 % in 2010 .

Context: How has the public sentiment about economic news changed?
Summary: Through it all , the public ’s perceptions of economic news have changed very little . Currently , 61 % say the news they are hearing about the economy is a mix of good and bad , 33 % say it is mostly bad and just 5 % say it is mostly good .

Context: Describe the public opinion on the number of immigrants entering the United States.?
Summary: The survey finds that a majority of the public ( 55 % ) believes that the number of immigrants entering the United States illegally is higher now than it was 10 years ago while about four - in - ten believe it is the same ( 27 % ) or lower ( 15 % ) today .

Context: Describe the pattern of education and population of Hindus worldwide ?
Summary: Nearly all ( 98 % ) of the world ’s Hindu adults live in these three countries , which explains why patterns among Hindus in South Asia align very closely with patterns among Hindus overall Worldwide , Hindu adults average 5.6 years of education , compared to a global average of 7.7 years for all adults

Context: What is the trend between white adults and Hispanic adults responding to the 2020 census?
Summary: White adults ( 79 % ) are more likely to say they have responded to the 2020 census than adults who are Hispanic ( 74 % ) or Black ( 66 % )

Context: Compare proportions of partisans hearing about the possibility of withdrawal of the U.S from Syria?
Summary: Republicans and Democrats are about equally likely to have heard about plans for withdrawal .

Context: Describe the trend in the opinion of Americans about U.S. Airstrikes against Syria.
Summary: Over just the past week , the share of Americans who oppose U.S. airstrikes in Syria has surged 15 points , from 48 % to 63 % , as many who were undecided about the issue have turned against military action . By contrast , the share of Americans who support airstrikes remains virtually unchanged : Just 28 % favor U.S. military airstrikes against Syria in response to reports that its government used chemical weapons .

Context: What was the trend in local tv operations in 2004 ?
Summary: In 2004 , the five largest companies in local TV – Sinclair , Nexstar , Gray , Tegna and Tribune – owned , operated or serviced 179 full - power stations , according to a Pew Research Center analysis of Securities and Exchange Commission filings data .

Context: Compare college completion rates among different races and ethnic groups?
Summary: As of 2014 , among Hispanics ages 25 to 29 , just 15 % of Hispanics have a bachelor ’s degree or higher . By comparison , among the same age group , about 41 % of whites have a bachelor ’s degree or higher ( as do 22 % of blacks and 63 % of Asians ) .

Context: Describe the proportion of Lebanese Muslims who supported terrorist acts in the name of Islam.
Summary: Despite Lebanese Muslims are among the most supportive of terrorist acts in the name of Islam . 39 % said suicide bombing and other forms of violence against civilians are often or sometimes justified in order to defend Islam from its enemies .

Context: How are women's roles seen by Americans?
Summary: Roughly half of Americans ( 51 % ) say it ’s better for a woman who wants to reach high political office to have children before entering politics , according to a 2018 Pew Research Center survey on gender and leadership . About a quarter ( 26 % ) say it would be better to wait until she is well - established in her political career , while 19 % say it would be better for a woman not to have children at all if she plans to seek higher office . Views are different when it comes to leadership positions in the business world . About a quarter of Americans ( 23 % ) say it ’s better for women who want to reach top executive jobs in business to have children early in their careers , 41 % say they should wait and 34 % say it ’s better for them not to have children at all

Context: How is the ownership distribution of cell phone according to age in adolescents?
Summary: Among 12 - 13 year olds , 52 % had a cell phone in 2008 . Mobile phone ownership jumped to 72 % at age 14 in that survey , and by the age of 17 more than eight in ten teens ( 84 % ) had their own cell phone .

Context: How is financial support do the Guatemalan immigrants send home?
Summary: Guatemalan immigrants around the world sent home $ 7.5 billion in remittances in 2016

Context: How do Americans view the death penalty?
Summary: A majority of Americans favor the death penalty for those convicted of murder , but support for the death penalty is as low as it has been in the past 40 years . 56 % favor the death penalty for people convicted of murder , while 38 % are opposed .

Context: What are opinions about feelings about the health care?
Summary: According to the Census Bureau , 16.1 % of Americans ( nearly 49 million ) were uninsured in 2009 ; by 2014 , the last year for which there are data , only 10.4 % ( almost 33 million ) Americans lacked health coverage .

Context: Describe Democrats confidence in Mueller's investigation.
Summary: By contrast , seven - in - ten Democrats and Democratic leaners are very ( 43 % ) or somewhat ( 27 % ) confident that Mueller ’s investigation will be fair .

Context: What are adults' opinions about how rewarding helping their ageing parents is?
Summary: Most adults who have helped an aging parent see it as rewarding . Among those who have helped their parents in a matter of ways , 88 % say it ’s rewarding .

Context: Describe Americans opinions about U.S. public schools.
Summary: just 18 % say U.S. public schools rank above average or higher internationally , while 41 % of Americans say public schools are below average ( 37 % rate them as average ) .

Context: What is the average annual household income for blacks ?
Summary: average annual household income for blacks was 60,613 rand ( roughly $ 8,700 at the then - current exchange rate )

Context: What do Americans think about Chinese economic power and what is their opinion about Chinese leadership?
Summary: Nearly three - quarters in the U.S. ( 72 % ) acknowledge that China plays a more important role in the world today compared with 10 years ago , and a third of Americans believe China , not the U.S. , is the world ’s leading economic power . However , 88 % of Americans say that having the U.S. as the world ’s leading power would be better for the world .

Context: Comment on the viewership of people on media covering the Oil leak incidence?
Summary: More than half of Americans ( 55 % ) say they followed news about the oil leak very closely . Close to six - in - ten ( 58 % ) say they followed this news more closely than any other major story .

Context: what is the impact of fertility trends in the U.S. by immigrant women?
Summary: Immigrant women play an important role in overall U.S. fertility trends . Between 1970 and 2014 , the increase in the annual number of U.S. births was driven entirely by immigrant women , while births to U.S.-born women fell .

Context: By providing percentages discuss news headlines that people focused on the most.
Summary: The recent price increases also come at a time of continued interest in the health of the U.S. economy ; 14 % say they followed news about the economy most closely last week . Fewer say they very closely followed news about a deadly earthquake in New Zealand ( 20 % ) or recent developments in the debate over gay marriage ( 19 % ) . Five percent say they followed news about the earthquake more closely than any other top story , while 4 % say they followed news about gay marriage developments that closely .

Context: Describe the trend in midcareer newsroom workers in comparison to workers aged 55 and above?
Summary: The number of full - time midcareer newsroom employees – defined as those ages 35 to 54 – dropped by 42 % between 2008 and 2018 , from about 52,900 to 30,800 workers , according to Census Bureau data . The number of newsroom workers ages 55 and older increased by 31 % during this period , from about 16,400 to 21,400 .

Context: What are Trump's approval rates among white evangelical protestants who regularly attend church in relation to those who attend church less often?
Summary: White evangelical Protestants who regularly attend church ( that is , once a week or more ) approve of Trump at rates matching or exceeding those of white evangelicals who attend church less often . Indeed , in the first few months of Trump ’s presidency , white evangelicals who attended church at least weekly were significantly more likely than less - frequent churchgoers to approve of Trump ’s performance ( 79 % vs. 71 % ) .

Context: What is the opinion of U.S. adults about scientists role in GM foods policy?
Summary: Despite mixed assessments of scientists working on genetic modification , six - in - ten U.S. adults ( 60 % ) say scientists should have a major role in policy issues related to GM foods and 28 % say they should have a minor role .

Context: What is the partisan trend in the American public satisfaction with the country?
Summary: Just 12 % of Americans say they are satisfied with the way things are going in this country today – a decline in national satisfaction and lower than at any previous point in Trump ’s presidency The partisan gap in levels of satisfaction has narrowed to just 12 percentage points , with 19 % of Republicans and Republican leaners and 7 % of Democrats and Democratic leaners now saying they are satisfied with the way things are going .

Context: Comment on views of registered voters about being outspoken on their presidential choice?
Summary: A majority of voters ( 58 % ) who currently plan to support either Trump or Clinton say they do n’t mind if people know who they support but that they do n’t go out of their way to say it . A third say that they are “ pretty outspoken ” with others about their support , while far fewer ( 7 % ) say that they would rather other people not know that they support one of these candidates .

Context: Explain the interest shown by public about Iraq situation?
Summary: The situation on the ground in Iraq was the most closely followed news story of the week Roughly three - in - ten Americans ( 31 % ) followed Iraq news very closely and 23 % listed this as the single news story they followed more closely than any other

Context: What is the opinion of registered voters about presidential election candidates ?
Summary: 51 % of registered voters support Clinton or lean toward her , while 42 % support or lean toward Trump . In a three - way contest , including Libertarian Party nominee Gary Johnson , 45 % favor Clinton , 36 % support Trump and 11 % back Johnson .

Context: Describe the trends in duration of unemployment since 2005?
Summary: The median duration of unemployment was 13.4 weeks in January While a considerable improvement over the recession ’s depths – median duration peaked at 25.2 weeks in June 2010 – this still is well above pre - recession levels ( which typically were around eight or nine weeks ) .

Context: What are the views in percentage on the coverage of the situation in Afghanistan versus the federal budget deficit and national debt?
Summary: Pluralities also say news organizations are giving the right amount of coverage to the situation in Afghanistan ( 42 % ) and news about the federal budget deficit and national debt ( 44 % ) . Relatively few see either story receiving too much coverage ( 12 % Afghanistan , 11 % federal budget deficit and national debt . )

Context: What is the opinion of Americans about makers of fitness trackers data ?
Summary: About four - in - ten Americans ( 41 % ) say it is acceptable for makers of fitness trackers to share users ’ data , a smaller share ( 35 % ) believes this is an unacceptable practice . Another 22 % are unsure if this is an acceptable practice or not

Context: How confident were supporters of winning candidates in the voting process?
Summary: In districts where GOP candidates for the House prevailed , 65 % of Republican voters say they are very confident votes in their community were counted as intended , while 53 % of Democratic voters in these districts say the same . And the pattern is reversed among voters in districts where Democratic candidates won : 62 % of Democratic voters in these districts say they are very confident in the vote count in their community ; 48 % of GOP voters in these places say the same .

Context: What is the public's opinion about the role of religious organisations in science policy debates?
Summary: The general public is closely divided in its views about the role of religious organizations in scientific policy debates . Overall , half of adults say churches should express their views on policy decisions about scientific issues , while 46 % say churches should keep out of such matters .

Context: Describe the change in the share of the middle-income population.
Summary: During the first decade of this century , the world experienced a significant rise in the number who could be considered middle income . The world ’s middle - income population nearly doubled from 2001 to 2011 . Looked at by share , the global middle class increased from 7 % of the world ’s population in 2001 to 13 % in 2011 .

Context: What do Americans think about US involvement in other countries?
Summary: Pew Research Center surveys find Americans saying the U.S. should mind its own business and let other countries get along as best they can .

Context: How do young adults tend to protect their privacy online?
Summary: They are more likely to have limited the amount of personal information available about them online , changed privacy settings , deleted unwanted comments on social media , removed their name from photos in which they were tagged , and taken steps to mask their identities while online .

Context: What percentage of public believe that the events in Ukraine are important to U.S. interests?
Summary: 48 % say events in the region are very important to the United States , up 17 points from April ( 31 % )

Context: What are the U.S. views on businesses providing wedding services to same-sex couples?
Summary: U.S. adults were evenly divided , with roughly half ( 49 % ) saying businesses should be required to provide wedding services to same - sex couples , and a nearly identical share ( 48 % ) saying that they should be able to refuse to provide services due to religious objections .

Context: Describe the proportion of the public that tends to be sympathetic to illegal immigrants who are in the US.
Summary: In general , about two - thirds of the public say they are “ very sympathetic ” ( 23 % ) or “ somewhat sympathetic ” ( 42 % ) toward immigrants who are in the U.S. illegally .

Context: How angry are conservative Republicans at the federal government?
Summary: Anger is most palpable among conservative Republicans – 41 % say they are angry at the federal government , the highest among any partisan group .

Context: Compare the number of foreign graduates who received work permits under OPT with number of people who received approval for H-1B visas in 2017.
Summary: In 2017 , a record 276,500 foreign graduates received work permits under OPT , compared with 108,100 people who received initial approval for H-1B visas .

Context: What partisans think about social advantages of white people?
Summary: The gap between Republicans and Democrats also is stark . Nearly eight - in - ten Democrats and Democratic - leaning independents ( 78 % ) say white people benefit a great deal or a fair amount from advantages unavailable to black people ; just 21 % say they do not benefit at all or do not benefit too much . The views of Republicans and Republican - leaning independents are nearly the opposite : 27 % say whites benefit a great deal or a fair amount from societal advantages , compared with 72 % who say they do not benefit at all or do not benefit too much .

Context: What opinions do most Americans say about coronavirus-related restrictions on public?
Summary: A sizable majority of Americans ( 68 % ) continue to say their greater concern is that state governments will lift coronavirus - related restrictions on public activity too quickly

Context: What was the voter turnout rates between the different races?
Summary: the turnout rate of eligible Latino voters has historically lagged that of whites and blacks by substantial margins . In 2008 , for example , 50 % of eligible Latino voters cast ballots , compared with 65 % of blacks and 66 % of whites .

Context: What are the most and the second most common reasons to have a gun?
Summary: 67 % cite protection as a major reason . About four - in - ten gun owners ( 38 % ) say hunting is a major reason .

Context: Explain the cause of gap of population and voters and the reason?
Summary: However , during those same four years the growth of the Latino vote continued to lag well behind the growth of the Latino population . This widening gap is driven by two key demographic trends : a high percentage of the new Hispanics in the population are either too young to vote or ineligible because they are not citizens ( Figure 1 ) . About 5.6 million Hispanics voted in the 2006 mid - term election , which historically draws far fewer voters than the quadrennial race for president . Latinos accounted for 5.8 % of all votes cast , up from 5.3 % in 2002 . That increase was largely a function of demographic growth .

Context: What is the support of people towards Obama and Romney today?
Summary: Currently , 51 % say they support Obama or lean toward him , while 41 % support or lean toward Romney . This is largely unchanged from earlier in July and consistent with polling over the course of this year . Across eight Pew Research Center surveys since January , Obama has led Romney by between four and 12 percentage points .

Context: What opinion do the public have about Barack Obama ’s job performance as a president ?
Summary: 46 % approve and 49 % disapprove of the way he is handling his job as president . His overall rating is little changed over the course of 2015 . Obama ’s ratings for handling the economy ( 43 % approve ) and immigration policy ( 37 % approve ) are more negative than positive . He receives mixed ratings for his handling of global climate change ( 45 % approve , 40 % disapprove ) and race relations ( 44 % approve , 47 % disapprove ) .

Context: Describe the trend in Americans following economic news ?
Summary: Interest in news about the U.S. economy skyrocketed last week , with 70 % of Americans following economic developments very closely , up from 56 % the previous week .

Context: What countries have the lowest confidence in George W. Bush?
Summary: Just 10 % of Pakistanis express a great deal or some confidence in Bush to do the right thing regarding world affairs . Morocco ( 9 % ) , Turkey ( 8 % ) , and Jordan ( 1 % ) were the only countries to voice less confidence .

Context: What opinion do the people have about supporting Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping .
Summary: Within the region , Filipinos had the highest confidence in Xi , at 53 % , while the Japanese had the lowest at 11 % . In contrast , people in South Korea were more than twice as likely to have confidence in Xi than Trump regarding world affairs ( 38 % versus 17 % ) .

Context: What is the opinion of the different parties as to whether the United States should have gone to war?
Summary: Republicans ( 80 % of whom say the U.S. made the right decision ) and Democrats ( 30 % ) . A potentially ominous sign for President Bush is that the percentage of independents who think the U.S. was right to go to war has now dropped below 50 % for the first time ( 48 % )
